review:
i bounced off my time at portia quite hard so i was really surprised how much i really enjoyed my time at sandrock. 

is the game still far too grindy? yes. i really wish they could tone down how much busywork is in these games and the reliance of in-game timers to finish crafting items and juggling between multiple devices. but this is really my only strong criticism other than fairly weak combat.

but this life sim does one thing better than any other released this year or in recent memory - it creates a real sense of community and growth. my biggest bugbear about games like animal crossing is that you, the player, are the only person doing anything to help the world around you while everyone just sits pretty and asks you to do the work. sandrock has you working with other characters to produce a better world and that's great. is this a facade most of the time where you're doing exactly the same amount of work as in any other game? probably - but it helps to see the other builders put in work and to see donation boxes already partially full from other members of the community even if it is a trick. 

the characters are mostly pretty memorable and interesting - i usually struggle in other games of this type with remembering who is who, especially with romance-able characters who all seem bland and slapdash - and it does a good job of creating pricks in the community who you really wish you didn't have to deal with but have to because that's how a community is sometimes. 

the final 'act' of the game is quite special and while it had some of the grindiest components, i was glad i stuck through it because it was good to see how much of a difference i had made from when the game started and where i ended up in a way these games often don't really do. 

all in all, i highly recommend it as one of my favourite games of 2023 but i'd like to see future entries in the series maybe tone down the grind.

review:
as you can probably tell from the playtime, i adore this game. coming in at the 200 hour mark (and possibly a few more) is no mean feat.

my time at sandrock took the formula pathea started in portia and dialed it up to the next level. the game plays roughly the same. you're a brand new builder that arrived at a town that is in decline and it is up to you to turn your talents to improve the lives of those around you.

the gameplay loop is fairly simple. go out into the wilds, gather resources, bring them back to your workshop and get your machines turning out the components necessary to fulfill your commissions, upgrade your capabilities and home, repeat. to do this, you manage stamina as you gather materials and also engage in light, fairly simple combat.

what pathea does well is package this up in a charming setting with an amazing cast of characters. the graphics engine, while simple, is supported by a unique art style that allows for a wide range of colorful residents of sandrock while keeping the system demand to a minimum. my 7800x3d and 7900xtx are utter overkill for this game. that said, don't let the relatively mild requirements fool you - the game is beautiful. the art style is timeless, the town has a unique feel and the landscape vistas are wonderful. i found myself taking in-game photos of things to take advantage of the customizable portrait decorations you can hang in your house and, later, factory.

the engine does have a few hitches. the draw distance is rather poor and there aren't intermediate level of detail models. objects will sort of pop into existence and if you have the lod bias set to anything less than maximum, you'll see the outline of a bubble immediately around you while the supports on your workshop's border fence pop into existence. it also struggles with longer game sessions, so if you play four hours at a time, you'll start to notice pathfinding breaking or weird artifacts like bushes floating up in space out in front of the temple of the light.

all in all though, i find the graphics and engine appealing. there are a few hitches and bugs here, though nothing experience breaking.

what really makes sandrock shine is the world pathea created. running in parallel with the events of portia, sandrock casts you as a builder that arrived in the town of the same name. the town is suffering from severe decline due to decades of resource mismanagement and environmental degradation. water is in short supply and routine sandstorms buffet the town, slowly chewing away what little life is left in the area. had it not been for a rich deposit of old world ruins, the town would have long since died and been left to vanish in the dunes of the euphala desert.

the town is populated with a rich cast of colorful characters with their own distinct personalities. my personal favorites are cooper, a local rancher who has a habit of speaking in lengthy diatribes and has a conspiracy theory streak (i swear cooper's voice actor had more lines than the next five characters combined), and unsuur, a well meaning but not too bright local deputy who loves rocks a bit too much who i liken to a combination of drax from guardians of the galaxy and barnie fife from the andy griffith show.

surprisingly, the plot is actually quite deep. there is more going on than a simple tale of you building up stuff. there is banditry, a conspiracy and more going on that has a surprising climax. sandrock not only has an interesting story, it goes well beyond what a charming life sim should be and fleshes out the broader world of the free cities alliance and the surrounding nations.

my time at sandrock is a solid combination of life sim and narrative experience combined with a light factory inventory management game. if you're looking for a nice change of pace, you can't go wrong here.

review:
unpopular opinion but i wasn't a fan of my time at portia and found it kind of overrated, so i was very surprised when my time at sandrock ended up being one of my favourite games of all time. i've played a lot of life sim style games and this is one of the best by far - it's the only one i've played to rival my love of rune factory 4 in terms of gameplay, story and character dialogue.

i have 110+ hours in the game (started a bit before the 1.0 release) and i'm not even finished the main story quests yet, i thought i was almost done a while back and it turned out i was only 2/3 of the way through. there are always meaningful story events happening and new characters being introduced to keep things interesting. 

there are a lot of activities to do each day to stop things getting too monotonous - a mix of exploration, dungeon crawling, mining or hanging around town. you can also fish and farm, which i'm not too fond of doing in this game but are totally optional outside of a couple of quests. 

the characters are where this game stands out - the localization team did a great job with the dialogue because it's full of personality and can be pretty hilarious at times. the town is very lively with the characters all having different relationships to each other and having a lot of joint quests and scenes so it feels like a real community. one downside is the day to day dialogue lines can get kind of repetitive but there are a lot of character related events which is where the bulk of the content is. their faces are also not that expressive in dialogue which would be my main complaint, but the voice acting is very expressive and fills that gap. 

there are some bugs at the moment but the devs seem very active and engaged with the community. aside from the bugs the game feels very polished, and i'm honestly blown away at the sheer scale of it for a relatively small company. there is so much content, from the very long main story, to the numerous character quests, to the new locations, mines and dungeons to unlock. and unlike portia each mine/ruin feels unique and has distinct level design features to keep things interesting. honestly huge props to the devs for what they've achieved here, you can tell a lot of love was put into the game and they genuinely had fun with the world and characters they created (speaking of the world, the worldbuilding is pretty in depth and the setting is very interesting - i did love the concept of my time at portia despite my criticisms of the game, and that interesting history continues to be explored here).

review:
let me preface this by saying that i played my time at portia and didn't enjoy it at all. my time at sandrock absolutely blows it out of the water, and addresses my two most standout grievances about the first.

this time, they have designed the map properly so that your character never spends too long traversing from one location to another. the town map/level is beautifully made so that your workshop is never too far from any npcs you might need to reach/chat with daily. secondly, this is the most fun i've had with a towns' npc population in a while. a lot of cozy game developers forget to develop their characters beyond the basic, typical strokes. at first i felt like this would be the case for sandrock too, but i found myself genuinely enjoying a lot of the town's npc personalities that shine through their questlines. the writing isn't nearly the best i've seen in a game, but it's definitely a step above most cozy games i've played recently. at least more fun, if anything!

if i had to pick at any obvious downsides, i'd say that some voice actors are clearly uncomfortable in their characters' accents and inflections and it shows. i don't mind it too much but it might be grating to some.

as of the time of writing, i'm 40 hours in and i'm still being engaged with the game, so it earns my seal of approval.

review:
i picked up my time at sandrock as soon as it was available in early access. i enjoyed my time at portia and was excited to jump into this and be along for the development ride. if you enjoyed portia and haven't picked this up yet, i'd highly suggest you do so, you won't be disappointed.

i'm not much of a reviewer so he's my highlights.

good

-the visuals-the visual presentation is great. the style they started with in portia was kept for sandrock and tightened, cleaned, and it really pops. a straight improvement from its predecessor.

-characters-the characters fit with the world that these games take place in. goofballs on the one hand but can be serious on the other. it does a good job of portraying a tight knit group that has history with each other and rely on each other. the vas do a good job and you never really feel like its being phoned in.

-story-so, you've played some harvest moon games, stardew valley, and similar games...whelp, you know what kind of story you're getting into. that's not a bad thing though, we love those stories and that's why we scoop games like these up because while every story in these style of games has a similar foundation what's built on top of it gives us an insight into the biggest character in these games, the town. the town is a character all its own, a combination of its past, present, environment, and the characters living in, around, or otherwise interacting with it throughout the story. it takes on a life of its own and sandrock, as a town/character, is fun to see develop.

-qol-there were so many improvements to make life much easier in sandrock, it would almost make portia a little harder to go back to. but i very much appreciate everything they implemented in sandrock to make a builders life easier when it comes to making your shop hum along and get those contracts done. something a portia player can appreciate more than a newbie but a thumbs up from me.

bad

let me preface this by saying i'm not a tech savvy man, what you know about the power of rigs and all of the bells and whistles is probably beyond me so take this short section of bad with a grain of salt, your results may vary.

when i'd start up the game, while my load times were rather quick when i'd get into the game it could take a solid minute, at max, for the world to load everything. if i got into the game and i was loading in while in the house, that was fine but once i left the house or would load into a game that had me outside there could be a bit of a wait for things to load. i never found it a terrible thing but a rig that's a little on the lower end might have more of an issue.

the other thing i noticed is that if i played for a block of 3-4 hours in a row i could start to experience slowdown that became much more significant as the time would go on and control inputs would also be laggy. a couple times character path-finding became erratic and would be my prompt to log off. i haven't done blocks like that in a while and so i don't know if it's a concern and it may have just been my machine but i did experience that.

review: i like it

this is a general improvement of portia, with numerous qol improvements and better graphics.  if you want a chill builder sim game with a side of combat, this is a decent pick up.  that said there's a few things from the original that haven't improved:

-the combat is still too simplistic.  there are still no special attacks (the enemies get them, but not the player) so all you do for the most part is mash lmb and roll dodge once in a while.  there are ranged weapons, but having to constantly build more ammo is annoying so you'll just melee everything for the most part.
-the main story drags on way too long.  this was probably my main complaint about portia as well.  as another reviewer put it, there's an interesting major plotline where you fully expect the story to end afterwards but it drags on with more mundane busywork for another 10-15 hours.
-waiting on things.  you can speed up time to 3x speed at least without mods, but it can still take 15+ minutes of real time to smelt a stack of bars so a lot of the time you'll just toss stuff in and end the day to skip time.
-relation grind.  like the first game it is slow and tedious.  some characters aren't too bad because they constantly put up commissions which give a big chunk for something you want to do anyways, or are heavily involved in story missions.  others, like the doctor, require you go out of your way to talk to and constantly do boring crap like play critters (basically rock paper scissors with cards) over and over.  as a bonus middle finger, [spoiler]several characters leave partway through main story and get replaced by new ones[/spoiler].  hope you didn't waste your time on those ones!

overall though, it's a decent game for the price.  i never finished portia, i tried twice and got bored halfway through both times.  sandrock at least improved the gameplay enough to make me finish it this time.

review:
my time at sandrock have been a captivating and immersive gaming experience. from the moment i set foot in this post-apocalyptic world, i was drawn into its rich narrative, extensive crafting system, and the challenges it presented.

the landscape of sandrock is a visual treat, with its desolate beauty and a sense of exploration that kept me engaged for hours on end. the attention to detail in the environment and the variety of biomes made every journey exciting, whether i was traversing the  wastelands or navigating the mysterious ruins.

the crafting system is where sandrock truly shines. with a wide array of resources to gather and a plethora of blueprints to discover, i was constantly motivated to experiment and create new items, from weapons and tools to cozy furnishings for my humble abode. the feeling of progress as i upgraded my workshop and expanded my capabilities was incredibly rewarding.

the interactions with the colorful cast of characters in sandrock added depth to the story and provided a sense of community in an otherwise harsh world. building relationships with the townsfolk was an enjoyable aspect of the game, and their unique personalities and quests brought the game world to life.

while my time at sandrock was largely enjoyable, there were occasional technical hiccups and performance issues that could be frustrating. however, the frequent updates from the developers gave me hope that these issues would be resolved over time.

in conclusion, my 150 hours at sandrock have been a delightful adventure. the combination of exploration, crafting, and storytelling in this unique post-apocalyptic world made it a memorable gaming experience, and i look forward to further updates and improvements as i continue to explore and build in this engaging sandbox world.

review:
this is the first game i ever tried early access for, because even though portia had its issues on switch, i sunk several hours into it happily. i can firmly say i don't regret it for a moment. today is official launch day and even though my campaign will not be wiped, i'm excited to start over and enjoy everything again. this game sits perfectly at my interests. it's got a nice combat system, socializing, farming too, you can take quests at your own pace for the most part, you have so much customization for your character, house, and much more. yes, there is the very occasional non-game breaking bug, but those are always addressed by the devs and it feels like they listen to the fan base. you can really feel the love of the community and developers in this game. i can't wait to sink my teeth into 1.0.  thank you for my time at sandrock! i hope to see even more my time's!

update: 11/17/23

several more hours later and i'm starting to near the final missions. i just want to restate how good this game was. i'm honestly so happy with it. well done to the entire team.

from the start of last year when it was in early access, to today just before full release; it's been one good ol ride. this game had me feeling anxious to know what was going to happen next just like stardew valley was, and now fully completing it i'm happy to have had the honor of playing through the game. developers do not get enough credit that they should be getting for an amazing game made through the struggles of covid. 

highlights:
-different candidates for relationships/marriage
-tons of equipment/crafting to do
-many things to do as side quests if you need to get your mind away from the real world
-keeps you wondering what's gonna happen next

as i'm writing this, there is an update coming out on the 2nd of november that introduces more content, which i'm hoping means that there is more in store past that. other than that, would highly recommend to anyone who is a fan of my time at portia, stardew valley, and other sim games

review:
my time at sandrock is a fun farm/life sandbox game and the sequel to my time at portia, which i also recommend.

good:

housing is a big factor when it comes to farming games, in this game you can customize your farm however you want, you can make your land mainly like a factory, farm or a beautiful homestead while not worrying about the other two as much.

commissions are the main money maker in the game that also rewards you with a good amount of relationship for certain characters and workshop reputation points. i highly recommend doing these daily and picking the most profitable ones as money is more important than the other two rewards.

saving midday is not a common thing to happen in farm/life sim games and that is why i really like this game, (portia doesn't have this feature). also that comes with midday saves is when you complete a quest or commission you auto save and have a quick save which is really handy to have.

surprisingly enough as well as the previous game, there are english voice actors despite being an indie game from china, every secondary character is voiced by someone. while it isn't fully voice acted (unvoiced lines or grunts that don't match dialogue) it does offer a solid amount of voice acting when it comes to story events to make you really feel immersed.

there are a large variety of weapons, you can have 4 types of melee weapons, multiple ranged weapons and even some unique weapons that can't be crafted. each melee weapon has its own style and combo, whether it be daggers for fast but weak attacks or a greatsword which is slow but does a lot of damage.

decent:

relationships in this game follows every other farm/life sim game, there isn't a weekly limit but if you give an item too much they will like it less. the game is good at indicating if there is a relationship event going on as it will be marked on your map but the game doesn't really tell you if you even have events available for a character or if it is just end of current build.

there is a skill tree that you can do, but maxing out those 4 skills basically just fill up the entire tree leaving no real choice in the end. skill points are only gained by doing those specific skills. though i do think this idea is pretty neat, i will always prefer character levels rewarding skill points (portia did this).

farming had a step-up from portia, where you are able to place farming plots anywhere on your land instead of planter boxes. you can easily and efficiently plant items the higher the toolbox up to a 4x4 planting/watering/fertilizing area which is quick and easy. farming has some flaws as well, farming early game is terrible. since it is just inefficient. you have to apply a lot of fertilizer, water and straw just to make a profit, you can't automate farming either so you have to constantly be on watch to water.

bad:

!!they added the feature to group items and move them in bulk in the 1.0 update!!

moving housing items is a real chore, there is no area select so you have to move each individual item one by one (including farming plots). i would just recommend using your character instead at some points. moving your house with 2+ stories is also annoying as whenever you move it, you have to move each individual story top to bottom and if you had items in the house after reapplying those stories, some might get removed since staircases don't remember their last known location but instead have a predetermined location every time you add a new floor.

review:
i've played portia with dedication, so going into sandrock now, i immediately felt the immense upgrades and incredible amount of improvements overall compared to portia. everything looks better, even the stories are written and shown better, the characters are more fleshed out, there are so much more machines to build, farming is more detailed now, they really stepped up their game and there are more new features all around, and so on. i can say for certain they've done their very best to create this game and it's beautiful altogether.

i love the aesthetics of the ui, the way the models of everything look so much better, and despite being in a desert area (i'm not a fan of desert settings usually), this one still won me over with its vibrant vibe. because it's cozy - the houses are lovely and the design of the atmosphere is adorable - and the community really helps it, you can tell people of sandrock care for each other as you go through your days in it. there's so much more to sandrock than just sand and cacti. it's got sandstorms, monsters, bandits, dungeons and dark stuff to uncover, but even through all that, the morning comes and you're greeted with the local smiles and a bunch of sweet mail and cute gifts by your house door. you've become part of this community now.

sandrock is one of the best life sims/adventure games i've ever had the pleasure to play.

just as in the first game, "my time at portia," you are a builder tasked with helping the development of your town. it's a story that takes place in the future, after the apocalypse is over and the the planet has had time to recover. dig up artifacts to learn how to build technology of the past.

review:
overall: cautious recommend. it's a fun game if you're in the mood for it, but i've had technical problems that makes me hesitant to play full-heartedly or recommend in full confidence. 

there is lots of trial-and-error learning in this game. sometimes i'm in the mood for that and it becomes a really uplifting and encouraging game. other times it's not, and it becomes disheartening. i never played my time at portia myself (but i've seen others play it), so it's possible that those players would have a better understanding and more intuitive time than i do though. i actually love the atmosphere of this game more than my time at portia, which is strange for me as i'm not normally a western type of person. 

i've had this game crash several times pretty early on (during that first tutorial or before) on two different computers as well, and it heats up my gaming laptop very hot and very fast when i've never had that problem with any other game. i cannot pinpoint what the problem was, but i believe i've fixed it now because i managed to get through several hours with no crashing!

review: this game is definitely hitting that stardew valley vibe for me, but there are enough differences to make it feel really unique and compelling on its own. the desert location is a cool change of pace, and the mix of gameplay elements keeps me engaged and like i always have something to do. combat is pretty basic, and some of the voice acting is hilariously bad, but i don't really come to these games for those things so it's not that big of a deal. overall, i think this game is really one of the best in the farming/life sim genre right now. definitely worth playing if you're having stardew withdrawals or just want something new.

review:
i loved my time at portia; it was a phenomenal game in this genre and i played several full play-throughs.  sandrock takes everything portia did and makes it even better.  there's more of everything and with a definite upgrade across the board.  have only run across a few minor bugs from release 1.0, but nothing game breaking and no worries.  the game itself is just fantastic, from the main story line (which i've barely even scratched yet, it appears) to combat to socializing to the building up of your workshop and everything that entails.

the characters are excellent across the board, from the irritating to the awesome.  sandy the camel is a nightmare. amirah is a smoke show.  two characters that couldn't be further apart in a large roster of very interesting and diverse characters.  

imho, game is already a 10/10.  i hope pathea games continues with a third game like this.  would love to see one take place fully within an ice biome.   but this?  definite home run!

overall, a positive experience if you just want to chill! :3

review:
honestly, is a really fun game, but since its a farming sim, base building, town building, life simulation game, it can be a bit boring and slow. you don't need to rush, but you can do more, in the end though it won't help a lot because the game has day and night cycles, and your forced to actually sleep. so you cant keep going forever, this is not a mmo game(massive multiplayer online game).

so' it might be for you if:
1. you like to take your time
2. you like exploring
3. you like to interact with others 
4. you like farming and raising animals
5. you like helping others
6. you like building
7. you like grinding
8. you like non mainstream games


this game might not be for you if:
1. you like to run and gun
2. you like to speed run games
3. you like to skip dialog
4. you like to kill everyone
5. you hate interacting with others
6. you like playing the villain
7. you only like the most realistic immersive eye popping graphic fidelity possible
8. you only like mainstream games

review:
at first i thought this was going to be a fairly slow, uneventful game, kinda like stardew valley where honestly, nothing really happened...except i was wrong, the story picked up, the plot kicked off, the sandrockers (npcs) having character growths, the land physically changing from your actions, it felt like everything said and done had an impact on it all!
this, unfortunately, i felt portia to be lacking, so when i went into this, i thought it was gonna be another mta: portia clone with some slight alterations, boy how wrong i was!
when (most) of the people spoke, i paid attention, i was invested, i had to know what came next or if this would be brought up further on, it was such a fantastic story driven game, they've really come a long way from portia. and, i've found out recently that they're working on another mta game, with the placeholder name "project me" which has me so excited to see what they'll accomplish after witnessing this game!

i stepped into this game thinking i would play at most maybe 10-30 hours before having the same dry spell i had with portia and never pick it back up...248 hours later! i've finally finished the game...and i feel empty...this is a good thing, if you feel empty or sad that something is over, that means it had an impact on you, it means you were properly enjoying yourself, and seeing the story end, just makes you feel...lonely, that you're already missing it...i don't get that feeling often, when i finish a game i enjoy i just throw my hands up and go "done!" and moving on with my day, this, was one of those few exceptions.

i wholeheartedly recommend this game, is it flawless? of course not, but i will rate it at 8.5-9/10.
it had it's flaws, but non of them was enough to stop me from enjoying it, nor really anything game breaking (except for one but that is cause my save was made during ea, so i'd imagine majority of my issues was because of that)


i'm leaving you with a warning and an advice or two.
this...is not a relaxing game, even if they're trying to get it nominated for a "sit and relax" award, this game will stress the heii out of you, having to make sure you got enough materials, the right upgrades for your machines, the recipes themselves, it becomes a lot, so when you're given the option to buy the factory control panel, for the love of nia (it'll make sense in-game) get it immediately, it'll make your life so much easier.
another advice is to make sure you got the ads running which you can get gol, rep, and exp increased (you interact with the news board next to the city hall), if you're lucky, you'll get all 3 (you can cancel ad and get it again for new results, costs 100 gol each time)
get the talents that increases the gol booster from the ad, get more gol from same day delivery, aswell as the turning in items of higher rarity (need a refiner for that)
befriend yan (and much later wei)
do all this, and money will never become an issue.
and even cheese it up a bit and reduce the size of your house and roof for some instant fast gol, several thousands to be exact.


with all that said, all i can say is... happy building, and i'll see you! in their next mta game.

review: my time at sandrock was an absolutely fantastic addition to what i hope will be an ongoing "my time at -" series of games.  pathea worked out a lot of the shortcomings that my time at portia had, especially with inventory management.  there are still some bugs at full release, but they're usually not game breaking (i like to think my character t-posing to receive an award was just a power play move to show what a boss he is).  the characters and story are better fleshed out than some major titles, and i always was excited to explore what i could learn about the townsfolk.  after just shy of 100 hours, i beat the game with every side quest that came my way.  i presume i missed out on some character specific side quests due to story progression, but it felt like a natural pacing on my part.  can't recommend the game enough!

review:
one of my favorite games of all time. has the most complex social aspects i've seen in a game and what we usually all wanted for years with life sim games. other devs should take notes, honestly. 

the best part about this game: there is always plenty things to do, and they are all fun and useful, a lot of life sim games might have you build useless things. almost everything you build gets used in events, main story content, bridges to unlock new areas, oh, and there is always new places being unlocked as you progress, immersive atmosphere, new characters being introduced, and i mean years in-game. 408 hrs (continued from early access save) and i am still unlocking new characters, areas, story content.

all the characters are well voice and well written. and by well written---really, well written. i don't think i can play a harvest moon or story of seasons game after this tbh. it's spoiled me. the characters are fleshed out wonderfully, with their own thought out pasts, stories, you can talk about them in convo during play dates, or romantic ones. some characters have reverse confessions and characters have romance and friendship quests as well as multiple in story quests where other characters will talk and interact with you and eachother. i guarantee you will feel some emotion for every single one of these characters. characters i didn't like or care about before i got to know i grew to like later, their flaws and their traits both, and their stories. 

this is one of the most immersive games i've experienced. it makes you feel apart of the community, and the seratonin boosts you get just from speaking to villagers, getting gifts outside your house on your birthday or wedding day, having your partner ask if you'd like to spend the day together after marriage and take you on little dates when most games are like 'they are married, have kids' and it's either the end, or they are blank nobodies now that have no more content whatsoever! this game doesn't do that. 

if sandrock gets more content dlc or in the next my time game, if they decide to have a kid system, i'd rather no kids unless there is real content for them, this is what the people want pathea, even if you charge $ for it:

-family outings/content and story events with your child/partner, and with the townsfolk
-the child going to school/interacting with other children
-old enough to speak properly/help out around the work shop or be interested in another profession/maybe story content for the kid following qi or owen around if they wanted to work as a scientist apprentice/at the blue moon as a chef or waiter or something.  ((not neccessary, just would be super cute. i would just rather not have kids in a game, like how stardew did unless they have content, sandrock still beat the others for sure though.)) and maybe a better child system to know when your child needs something/bring them with you on a baby backpack or hire a babysitter if you can't be home.

i'm definitely doing another playthrough. it's easy to miss dialogue and content because there is so much((this is a good thing.)) we got so lucky with my time at sandrock and i feel like i would 100% die for any of the sandrockers fr. the story gets better and better. sometimes it's silly, sometimes it's serious, sometimes it's just fun. 

characters you befriend will someetimes show up outside your house because they miss you and want to hang out, and sometimes you will see a lot of ! events to unlock, where you can say to much is going on right now and get to it later.

you might walk into someones home and they are eating dinner together, arvios sister is visiting him, or the preacher is teaching jasmine how to speak politely if she didn't like an authors book. little details that bring life

oh, and don't get me started on the holidays. only game i cared about holidays. you have mini games on almost every one, from collecting ingredients on a yakmel and can bump into other people, grilling up food for the towns folk, a dance competition, and so much more.

on dates with friends and romantically, you can set off fireworks in a fun pattern of your choosing, draw in the sand, play whack a mole or games at the arcade, sit and talk on a bench or go out to eat and order them food. you can befriend folks easily without gift spamming. talking to them, being yourself and taking commissions/work on the request or commission board they asked for is helpful. some characters might need to unlock events to get there story or even be able to give gifts to them if they are more to themselves.

the personalities are well thought out. characters with pasts, multiple hobbies likes and dislikes, where most games the 'fisherman' is just a fisherman and nothing more, his entire personality. you will hear them talk about their family, their other interests, and things they like. the characters entire personality isnt just a trope or based around 1 thing. this is the best character development as well for some characters i've seen in a long time. i highly reccomend buying this. it will be a blast constantly.

usually life sims have moments when your bored. well 400 hrs in and still constant content. i'm just saying....i hope this becomes the new standard for life sims xd

review:
the plot for this game was a lot more engaging than i expected, and most of the npcs are likable (or if they're not, it feels intentional, y'know?). the gameplay loop is satisfying. it is long though, be prepared for that. even so ... it hasn't felt like it's dragging for me at any point. it's just ... stuff keeps happening!

it's not perfect, the house construction aspect is janky and you can tell which characters the writers were more invested in sometimes, and some of the late game cutscenes need another pass to show the builder looking at people talking to them instead of staring blankly into the middle distance, but overall if you like gathering stuff to make stuff to make plot happen, this game will likely please you.

review:
honestly pretty good from start to finish as a single player game. i'd like to echo what i've seen in other reviews that the dialogue could have definitely been trimmed down. i also still think that the "mini game" portions like sand fishing and events like the dance off are extremely lacking to the point where i just never felt like participating in them beyond the first time. that wasn't a huge deal since none of it was really required and i finished the story before too much of it looped around (which is kinda where i stopped, after the credits roll it's pretty much just a sandbox since i did all the sidequests that had popped up already).

beyond that i feel my biggest gripe was the "iffy" pathing that really takes me out of it sometimes, seeing npcs just teleport around, or slowly teleport into frame for cutscenes was kinda jarring, i wish they would "try a bit harder" before just giving up and teleporting

overall i loved my experience but it definitely feels like it could use a 1.1 or 1.2 patch to iron some problems out

review:
my time at sandrock is a charming sequel that gracefully expands on the world of my time at portia, offering a serene yet captivating experience in the desert town of sandrock.
players are welcomed into a world teeming with possibilities‚Äîrebuilding workshops, cultivating crops, and forming meaningful relationships with the townsfolk. the customization options allow for a personal touch, making every decision purposeful.
visually, sandrock is a treat. the desert landscapes are beautifully rendered, transitioning seamlessly between peaceful vistas and the occasional sandstorm, adding depth to the exploration.
the soundtrack complements the atmosphere wonderfully, enhancing the game's immersion. it's a subtle yet effective element that enriches every moment in this charming world.
the storytelling engages, slowly revealing the town's lore through quests and interactions. the developers' commitment to engaging the community is evident, with regular updates and a responsive support system.
overall, my time at sandrock offers a serene escape into a delightful sandbox world. while not without flaws, it's a pleasant and engaging experience that will undoubtedly appeal to genre fans.

review:
this is an early review and i didn't play portia, so i don't have a lot of deep perspective into history or whatever.

for positives, it's fun for building and gathering. there always seems something to explore or do, many things i have not tried yet. there are some fun story lines. there is a lot of good voice acting and characters. i have been enjoying it and want to get more hours in.

for constructive criticism...

the game seems to get in the way of itself sometimes; multiple story lines colliding, arising every single day to a cut scene,  several people outside or unable to traverse the town without triggering a cut scene or multiples in a single day. i think it is clear the developers wanted lots of story and that is great. it was just sometimes i was so sick of cut scene over and over, i just wanted to move on and complete a quest or do my goal so would just click thru. other times did not realize cut scene would prob never trigger again and wish for opportunity later. not a game dev, so i don't know how to balance this kind of stuff, and understand i am a halfway try-hard that might push to many quest lines too early, but also say things seem unbalanced in this respect. 

otherwise pretty fun! hope they keep working on it.

review:
*review especially for console players (switch lite & oled steam deck)* - i originally bought this game for my switch lite. i was happy enough with the performance because it was a huge improvement over my time at portia on the switch. after playing 30+ hours i decided that this was a top game for me. it's amazing! but then i discovered that the switch game does not have the complete game... no kids and missing quests and such. lame.

a few weeks prior to this, i had looked at the steam deck. decided to not get it at that time. when i found out that my time at sandrock was the full version on pc, i went back to looking at the steam deck and saw the new oled version! well, i bought it. the oled steam deck is bigger than the switch lite by a fair bit, but i usually play while sitting in a chair anyways so i just rest it on my legs. the performance of the oled steam deck is incredible. my time at sandrock also plays extremely well on the oled steam deck. it plays pretty much like on the switch lite for button functionality but better because i actually went and changed around some control things. the graphics are incredible on the steam deck. i am so thrilled that i made the change over because this game is so much better on the steam deck. the load times are much less, the graphics are way better, and the game just runs smoother. 

for new players, you can change the run button from hold down to toggle. this makes running way easier. i also changed the interact button from y to a because it just makes more sense for me. a was the jump button originally. you can also turn off the yakmel station cut scene!!! thank goodness!

review for the game - this game is awesome. i mean, i really bought a oled steam deck for it. i enjoy playing on a console more than a pc, but this game has the best performance as a pc game and it is also the full game that is currently out.

i have played most of the story of seasons/harvest moon games, stardew valley, my time at portia... farming rpg's are my thing. this game is my favorite out of all of those. i felt like stardew valley was incredible for the huge world and opportunities, but that the character interaction was lacking. sandrock has a huge world, lots of things to do, and amazing character interaction. the storyline is huge and there are heaps of side quests that make me feel like i am involved in a story and town. it is simply amazing. usually, i don't care to romance multiple bachelors but... i feel differently in this game. these characters have depth that you just don't usually have in other games like this.

devs, you have done amazing work, and if you keep coming out with games like this, i will keep buying them. all the little improvements of game life are appreciated. how you can toggle through all your storage bins is great. having items in your storage at your disposal when filling requests and building things, amazing. you guys did a fantastic job. thank you! this is quite possibly my favorite game that i have ever played. 

gameplay tips for new players - for the first week in the game you get free access to the recycle junk area, go there everyday and break it all down. build three recyclers and stay on top of recycling all of it. for the first week you get half off at by the stairs. buy a storage box from there everyday of this half of week. use all your energy everyday, and do a commission everyday. just keep grinding it out. when the mines open up, make bronze bars as much as you can. upgrade your tools as soon as you can from the basic ones.

review:
this is a wonderfully adorable game that only builds upon the wonderful ideas that my time at portia started.  i still love the whole "ruined technological world" aesthetic and enjoyed all the references to your hard-working builder in portia.

i found the story even more interesting than the portia story and really enjoyed having a more friendly nature with your "rival" builder, unlike in portia.  i felt very invested in sandrock and really like how invested i got into the well-being of the town.

i have thoroughly loved every minute of this game, but i do feel that the end game becomes a little tedious.  once you get past the climax of the story and are only left with the city development stuff, story events start getting spread out and since most of your building is pretty self-sufficient due to the stockpiled resources, days can become quite empty and unfulfilling.  additionally, while i like some romances being unavailable until later in the game (same as in portia), some of the options only appear super late, making it a slog to make friends with or romance the last few people.

while i think these are valid criticisms, i still wholeheartedly love this game and look forward to putting many more hours into it.

review:
mtas is, from the get-go, very similar to its predecessor my time at portia and for the most part that holds true as this was supposed to be an expansion before turning into a separate project.

does it separate itself enough to warrant a separate purchase? i believe so, although i believe the price increased since early access when i purchased it.

initially i was put off by the chosen setting as having a farming game be set in a desolate desert setting seemed like a tall order but the developers managed to introduce new mechanics to account for this without removing one of the core parts of the original game. i will not go into detail as some of these mechanics are also tied to the story which is appreciated as well. they may seem a bit tedious at the beginning but eventually as with the previous games most of the energy/water requirements become trivial from simply farming out other resources which i find to be nice as the game is already pretty grindy as its predecessor was in some aspects. a quick tip: do try to get a pet asap as they help a ton.
how grindy the game feels however depends on what you as the player would like to do and how stressed you feel about worker of the month/year nominations. if you want to keep ahead you will be farming 3-4 commissions daily as well as blowing all your stamina in abandoned ruins which can become a bit of a repetitive chore (for me this feeling started somewhere around winter 1st year). in order to avoid this i would recommend engaging with other parts of the game as well (hangouts/romance/building the house/farm) and not feeling like you need to squeeze out every ounce of stamina out of every day otherwise you will burn out quickly.

in terms of the story i still have not reached the complete conclusion but i believe nobody expected this game to bring out a game of the year contender in this regard.
if there is one thing however i would say that the pacing feels off for me. lot of the progression is gated by arbitrary amounts of days that have to pass in order for you to even receive an email that will tell you (at the beginning of a given day) that the story will continue 2 days from now. after those 2 days pass you usually go to a fireside meeting where they will say something usually followed by another day or 2 of waiting which became a real point of frustration as i already blew through all the mining/building content and needed story to progress to access the 3rd abandoned ruins which never seem to come. at this point i am in year 2 spring and i have been done with all that 2nd abandoned ruins offer in year 1 day 26 autumn which means i spent most of winter just running around hoping a side-quest would appear or the story would hurry up and come but it never did as from what i read i am still a few mysterious letters off from actually getting to the ruins. feels like i am being drip fed story at this point which would be fine if i was not done with everything i can do in a given day at about 3pm with plenty of time to spare.

hangouts/romance are pretty similar to what they were in portia but i appreciate the variety of characters that are available although i do miss papa bear. i thought sandy was going to be a nice replacement for papa bear for me but the sound that camel makes evoke some primordial feelings of horror in me so i avoid her usually.
one thing that i find odd is how easy it is to become a bff with heidi specifically since many of the commissions are from her so even if i do not really care about her she is my best friend stat-wise since avoiding her commissions would be hamstringing my progress too much. of course with addition of a bounty board this levels out a bit as those requests (at least in my experience) came from a variety of characters usually not requesting standard commissions like elsie for example who in my play-through appeared on standard commission board maybe twice with a incredibly simple request that yields almost no rewards.

all in all it might seem like i am airing my grievances with the game which is true but i still really like it for what it is. it may not be perfect owing to the points above or the bugs which still plague it but i do believe it is a great experience for people who liked the first game and builds upon it well. the grind feels satisfying when done in moderation and there are a lot of options for customizing your yard and house. romance options are plenty and compared to the first game there seem to be more post-marriage content.
i do hope future brings more bugfixes and even content if we should be so lucky.

p.s.
if a sequel ever comes i do hope for a different environment though as portia was also 1/3 if not 1/2 desert which i understand is a rather major plot point in the overall story but i am kind of over sand now, thanks.

review:
this game blew me away!

i‚Äôve never heard of portia, or pathea games, and stumbled onto this game google searching games like stardew valley. 
on its surface, i wasn't too excited. a goofy looking cartoon game by a company i never heard of, set in a dusty western dystopia?  and the simplistic mechanics and combat didn't exactly have a "wow" factor.

but the more i played, the more i got sucked into the story.  into the idea that i am revitalizing a town.  into the character development.  into building up my workshop.
and the tons of quality of life features! the game is simple, sure, but relaxing simple, not boring simple. it's such a joy to play!

and what really speaks volumes, is the anecdote that i also played baldur's gate 3: a game i fully enjoyed and whose devs i support. but, i got bored before finishing it, and when my "hours played" for my time at sandrock surpassed my bg3 hours, i decided i really had to give credit where credit is due.  

definitely try this game!

review:
this is 2 games in one. i play multiplayer and single player and i'm so wonderfully surprised that there's new things to experience in both modes. multiplayer has its own missions/focus when i play with friends. when i play single player, it has it's own story and depth that is very different from multiplayer. so to me, going back and forth doesn't feel repetitive to me. 
what i loved about multiplayer that made it stand out from the crowd is that the host does not have to be online to play. anyone can hop in at anytime and that was a huge game changer for me. 

achievement hunters take note: no achievements can be earned in multiplayer. they are single player exclusive. 

as for the actual gameplay, it's been jaw droppingly sensational. i played my time at portia, and i went from not wanting to marry anyone because the character models were bleh, to now wanting to marry everyone because they're all hot!

for real though, if you played portia, this is an absolute must to play. no doubt about it. there's improvements across the board. if you've never played portia, but liked stardew or rune factory, then get this game. its not just farming. it has combat, building, workshop customization, story, collecting, etc. just about anything you'd want in this kind of game. 

there really isn't anything else i can say that other comments haven't already mentioned. it's been so fun and i will be playing many more hours. 9/10

review:
my time at sandrock is overall, a pretty great game that i enjoy a lot but a few issues i have make me really struggle to fight through to the bright spots. the characters and world building is great and so far there's really no end in sight for my progression, but every now and again i hit hard walls where the game requires me to wait in game time or just grind out resources to get to the next section. this especially goes with getting given quests that first require upgrading your equipment. besides that my only other complaint would be that the day cycle feels really short? it's odd that a life sim is giving me so much latent stress in having to run around and organise my time- when other games do it they tend to rely less on extremely restrictive timed quests, but sandrock has a bunch of those.

that said this games loop, nursing this town to health and the peaks at the world before are great. the romances are really cute too.

review:
fantastic game, i immensely enjoyed my experience playing it. while not perfect, it massively improves on many aspects from its predecessor, my time at portia (mtap), while successfully experimenting with new ideas. most of my gripes with the game are largely small, inconsequential things, though there are a couple that really stood out as being almost impressively bad for such a great game. overall i loved it and i'm crushed that my play-through has ended. 8.5/10

[h3] pros [/h3]
 - huge boost in qol from mtap; inventory management is a dream, voiced dialogue is consistent instead of feeling random, you have more freedom to explore, and so on 
 - performance; i have a gtx 1070 and an i7700k so my rig is definitely aging...however i was easily able to keep my fps at 70+. the only dips were when most/all of the cast was on screen at once and was moving around (some firesides, but oddly not an issue during any of the festivals)
 - content; i just finished all the quests and my save file reads at 144 hours. there is a shockingly gargantuan amount of content to play through. while there are always "fetch this" quests, very few felt like their main purpose was to add filler *coughacvalhallacough* and the main quests carried a strong identity (sandrock is a dying town and constantly goes from crisis to crisis)
 - cast/writing; i felt most of the vas did a great job and overall the writing did a great job in both conveying humor and seriousness. every quest you take with justice + unsuur is full of golden dialogue, burgess is wonderfully self-aware, and so on.
 - music; a major step-up from mtap. i mean, the musical score for mtap wasn't bad per se...well the combat music and ruins exploration music were both pretty...okay everything but the sparring music was pretty mediocre (the sparring music slapped). mtas has a much, *much* better musical score in essentially every aspect.
 - impact; you as the protagonist have a large and meaningful impact in the game. sandrock goes through a food crisis, water crisis, vegetation crisis, and you can visually see the effects they have on the town, both before and after. it made me feel, in my opinion at least, like what i was doing was...purposeful, helpful. 
 - combat; they really stepped up the combat from mtap and it is a much smoother and more enjoyable experience. there are distinct weapon types: [strike] dual blades [/strike] daggers, greatsword, [strike] insect-less glaive [/strike] spear and [strike] sns [/strike] sword + shield, along with some guns, throwables, and a couple unique weapons. 
 - quality; less of a "pro" and more of "not a con", any game where items/gear posses quality tiers is fraught with danger. sandrock does a great job with quality (aside from the names, i mean ordinary -> oustanding -> perfect -> rare doesn't make sense to me). you can refine many items/weapons/gear to raise their level at the expense of a couple gems/minerals and it never feels like a brutal grind to do so....except for any item that wants agate to level up, agate sucks to get. literally everything else though is totally fine.
 - creativity; as mentioned sandrock is built on a pitifully small oasis. it used to be lush but has been almost entirely claimed by desertification. mechanically, the game requires you to use water to "cool" your machines (water being one of the very few parts of the game that remained an actual obstacle throughout the play through). you are not allowed to cut down any trees within the boundaries of sandrock proper (early game finding wood is a unique challenge). these, along with taking over a dozen kinds of scrap into the new recycling machines, do a fantastic job of mixing up game play and how new tiers of materials get introduced.

[h3] neutral [/h3] 
 - skill tree; your experience gets both added to a total, overall level (health/stamina) and divided into either social, gathering, workshop or combat based on where the xp was earned. this is a mixed bag for me because the perks are very obviously either "must-haves" (+1 break damage, +1 daily commission) or "super terrible" (any of the *many* perks that give you +10% xp/chance for/etc). the extra xp is bad because....

[h3] cons: [/h3] (review too long, only showing the two that plagued me)
 - difficulty; the game is easy. no, that's not fair. it is stunningly, disappointingly, shockingly easy. i'm not asking this to be dark souls; if i wanted that i'd...go play dark souls. what i mean is that i was over-leveled (>= 8 levels above) for 90% of the game,  and massively over-leveled (>= 14) for about 40% of it. the greater the level difference, the less damage is taken/received a-la borderlands style. immunity frames when dodging are [i] incredibly [/i] generous; you have i-frames for the entire animation and a little extra, meaning you can just chain rolls for invulnerability and you can lazily roll through the few environmental obstacles thrown at you. however, as you are far above the recommended level, you won't even be dodging because you barely get hurt. the bosses are actually well designed, far better than mtap...but again, you don't need to engage in any of their mechanics you are a much higher level than they. also there are 0 attacks that cannot be avoided by simply....running in a different direction. earned experience points are also far too generous. sparring pen and the dive buzzard near the railroad tracks were the only two fights that i felt challenged; every other combat experience was a cake-walk. pathea could slash all earned xp by 25% and *maybe* you'd fall into the recommended range, but only if you never explored, did side quests or commissions. this is why 40% of the skill tree feels pointless. every perk doesn't need to be in perfect balance...but i'm already stomping everything i do not need a 10% chance to get double experience for kicking trees. gear cannot be used it you are below it's specified level but, once more, that had 0 effect on my gameplay outside of the first couple in-game weeks. sandstorms are supposed to be deadly, you are told to either stay inside or don protective gear. spoiler, it doesn't matter. wear whatever you want. the game makes some light attempts into platforming (which were done well) with the exception of the massive arrows that always tell you where to go. i could go on; suffice it to say i loved so much of the game but i never really felt "challenged" at virtually any point.
 - path finding. i mean wow, i was blown away by how unbelievably abysmal the path finding is. i've watched sandrock residents get stuck walking into building corners, get stuck walking into plants, decorations, each other, things that are invisible to me yet inexplicably manifest a collision box, animals, fences...if it exists in game, they've gotten stuck on it. repeatedly. in the first 3 minutes of the game you are offered a tour by the ten-year-old jasmine who after saying, "follow me" immediately turns around and gets stuck on a rock. the "solution" was to cause a character to fade out and reappear after they fail to move in their desired direction for a couple seconds. they only sometimes do that. sometimes they just give up and stand there until something breaks their error loop (if you host a party expect to talk to everybody constantly so they dont freeze in place). sometimes the pathing routes of everybody (enemies included) get shifted. now the bumble ants that are on the hill 200 feet to the east of your workshop eternally try to path into your fence. if a sandrocker has been catastrophically shifted from their normal route you may watch as they teleport back and forth between two spots (looking at your pen, rocky and krystal). your children are a complete enigma and refuse to abide by any pathfinding laws. good luck trying to change that diaper before you lose relationship with them and your spouse because they crawled outside the clearly-defined boundaries of your home.

review:
while it's not perfect, my time at sandrock does a great job of balancing all the core things you're looking for in a farming sim (plus some unique and surprising things from other genres) and is worth its full price for the quality and amount of gameplay you're getting.

more than it's predecessor, this game does justice to its setting and theme - it's hundreds of years after the apocalypse occurred in near-future world, and society's rebuilt using the scraps, so you've got a charming mix of old west cliches, retro-futuristic salvaged technology, and eclectic plotlines that include cold war politics, the threat of mutant sentient animals, and the collapse of the environment. aesthetically pretty much everything has improved from the character models to the environmental design. 

one of the most interesting things this game does is up-end the typical farming sim tropes to fit its setting and story. when you start, instead of cutting down countless trees or laying out plots of crops, you're salvaging scrap wood, weeds and dewdrops, always at risk of running out of water. then you're diving into ruins for copper and old circuit boards, and eventually you're fighting mutants and robots for advanced computer chips and high-quality alloys, building back an environment where you can safely cut down trees and plant massive fields without guilt. it's not really a factory game and there aren't a ton of interactive tools/machines to build to make things easier, but there's still something satisfying about building up the machines and seeing the improvements you've made around town.

characters aren't that deep but they've done a good job not only on improving the visual complexity of their design but also adding some interest to their story-lines. it's legitimately hard to choose which marriage candidate to focus on as there's a lot of good options for both men and women. there's some of fun twists and character development you wouldn't normally see in a farming sim, though overall the plot and dialogue is very pg. there's not much in the way of major character relationship drama or more mature/realistic themes.

later on the game can get kind of slow as you wait until the next day to continue quests, and the need for money/resources/relationship points disappears. in the options menu, there's an option to speed up the passage of time during the day up to 3x, or slow it down significantly, so you don't feel rushed while collecting resources, or bored waiting for machines to complete. this feature is honestly one of the best things in the game as it gives you a ton of control over the pacing.

the combat isn't great - it's pretty easy and attacks/hitboxes feel a bit awkward - but it's more complex than stardew valley or dinkum, and has some interesting mechanics and boss fights; it's most comparable to rune factory. you're not playing a farming sim because you expect it to be dark souls.

if like i do, you consider stardew valley and rune factory be the (recent) defining games of this genre, my time at sandrock is definitely up there in the top 5.

more quests - better written story and plot (heavy handed with the eco side of things, but makes sense given the subject matter.)

highly recommend - overall an improvement over my time at portia (not required to play the first game to understand the story or world either.)

review:
[h2] multiplayer feedback for my time at sandrock [/h2]

firstly, we want to express our appreciation for the unique multiplayer experience you've introduced in my time at sandrock. after investing over 50 hours+ into the game, my wife and i compiled our thoughts and feedback, focusing primarily on the multiplayer aspect. it's important to note that our feedback pertains exclusively to multiplayer, as we have yet to explore the single-player mode.

[b] let's delve into the areas that could use improvement: [/b]

[h3] 1. lack of freedom in a server-based world [/h3]
the introduction of a server-based world is both a blessing and a curse. while the ability to play even when the host is inactive is commendable, it restricts player freedom. in contrast to the multiplayer mechanics of [b]stardew valley[/b], where an account-based server offers players the freedom to modify the game using mods, console commands, and more, [b]my time at sandrock[/b] a sandbox multiplayer game focus falls short in this regard.
[list]
[*] comparison with stardew valley multiplayer

stardew valley allows mods and extensive customization, adding costumes to npcs, changing npc portraits, incorporating extra heart events, enhancing ui, introducing new characters, implementing console commands, even freezing time and more. the only limitation is the necessity for the host to be active, a trade-off that hasn't posed a significant issue, since i can just turn on my pc (i'm the host) and let them do whatever they want in the farm, even if my character faints due to lack of sleep, there are no adverse consequences or losses incurred because of the mods.

[*] impact on gameplay experience

the current server-based setup in [b]my time at sandrock[/b] detracts from the immersive storytelling experience. if one player is offline, progressing through quests and other activities becomes challenging due to the accelerated passage of in-game time. this time constraint induces stress rather than fostering a relaxing gameplay environment. the server is very strict when modifying our own world.
[/list]

[h3] 2. time progression does not stop in multiplayer mode even if you are alone. [/h3]
[list]
[*] a notable drawback of the server-based approach is that in multiplayer worlds with only one active player, time relentlessly marches on regardless if you are in menu mode, inventory, etc. this poses a challenge for players who meticulously plan and min-max their activities, especially when friends are offline. try to implement a "private/account based" multiplayer world, allowing players to host their own servers, would offer a solution to this predicament and empower players to play the game on their terms. ( some might say, stop playing and wait for your friends to get online ). 
[i]that would counter the fact that the multiplayer server-based is [b]useless[/b] since we have to wait for everyone to be online, right?[/i]
[/list]

[h3] 3. achievements and milestones in multiplayer [/h3]

[list]
[*] adding achievements to multiplayer mode seems to be a missed opportunity. while the game already features milestones, incorporating a system to track personal achievements and synchronizing them with steam achievements would enhance the multiplayer experience. if some achievement is only accessible in singleplayer, then we would have another reason to play the singleplayer mode.

[*] yes, you can play multiplayer mode for 500+ hours, complete everything you need and you still have 0/60 achievements. 
not cool.
[/list]

[h3] 4. shared storage challenges and quest completion [/h3]

[list]
[*] the existing shared storage system, offering capacities of 80(?), 120, and 300 at levels 1, 2, and 3, respectively, introduces significant challenges, particularly during the [b]early and mid-game phases[/b]. this challenge is accentuated in multiplayer scenarios where multiple players contribute to the shared storage. once the shared storage reaches its capacity, we're compelled to resort to "personal storage," limiting access for other players.

[*] the inconvenience arises when different players hold distinct resources, gone offline then other players need those items for quests. they will have to farm again, since time does not stop. unlike the seamless, automatic quest item retrieval feature present in single-player mode, the multiplayer experience introduces additional complexities, requiring deliberate coordination among players to ensure efficient quest completion.
[/list]

[h3] final note [/h3]

since this review is heavily focused on the multiplayer mode, we regrettably find it necessary to vote "do not recommend" for players specifically seeking a satisfying multiplayer experience. we remain hopeful that future updates will address these concerns, and we are open to revising our review once improvements are implemented.

review:
i'm really enjoying the game!  at the time of this review, i've played for almost 50hrs, and i'm almost done my fir4st in-game "year." sandrock's story lines are well thought out and develop the world and the characters well.  i'm honestly charmed. 

personally, i've experienced almost no bugs, aside from a random npc walking through a cut-scene (why burgess why), and events and quests seem to be triggering properly.  i had one instance where a story quest messed up the trigger event for a festival, but the game didn't actually skip it-- it just moved the actual festival events to two days later in-game.  

overall, great job to the developers--you can really see their growth since portia. :)   if anything changes as i progress further, i'll update my review.

review:
he's a 10, buuuuut.....

overall this is a pretty good game, and there's a lot of fun to be had in it. despite my negative review, i will keep playing it. and if you like games like stardew valley, you'll almost certainly like this one. the basic gameplay loop is fine - great even, if a little stale after awhile. and the story - likewise very enjoyable! the characters are, for the most part, unique and interesting and generally quite humorous. overall i should be able to recommend this game. so why don't i?

it's the little things. lots and lots of little things. for me, i play a game like this as a kind of escapism. i lose myself in the story and in getting to know the cast of characters - however cheesy it all might be. and in general, this game provides that better than most you might play, without the heaping dose of grim reality and tragedy you'll get from something like baldur's gate 3. it's a happy escapist fantasy. until you encounter (not bugs, because i did not encounter any that were not ultimately harmless and funny) some of the poorly or lazily implemented features.

obviously, you can date and marry and have kids with a good number of the characters. this is to be expected of this genre, and the process of getting to know these characters, through a variety of quests and events both focused on them and not, is quite a bit of fun. you will probably become quite invested in them. until you finish their content and they become hollow and uninteresting shells. they don't do or say anything new or interesting past a certain point - which is to be expected, but it is exacerbated by other things as i will point out. the dating/hangout mini game becomes a chore because after a couple of those you will have exhausted the dialogue with a given character - and that dialogue will not update even if you are actively in a relationship or married to the character. 

to make matters even worse, the story will not take any of this into account. whether or not you are dating a given character, or married to them even, will never come up outside of the one off wedding event or when talking to that character directly to get one of their canned lines of repetitive marriage dialogue - which are cute sure enough, but you can only hear them so many times before they lose all their charm. 

for a truly horrible example of how absurd this can get, at one point during the story you are to venture into a toxic environment full of extremely hostile enemies that want to kill you. all well and good, yea? well, if you are married to one of the characters involved, that character could be pregnant at the time of this quest. this does not come up...so your fun little happy escapism is irreparably ruined because the game is now sending your pregnant wife into a life and death situation because the smallest effort was not made to actually integrate the relationship and marriage system into the story in any way. 

and speaking of pregnancy, it's hilarious - from  a male character's perspective, i do not know how it differs if you play a female character and are the one to get pregnant. you will be teleported one morning to the hospital to see your spouse holding the baby, you will be prompted to name it, pick what the child will call you, and then you will be returned home. your spouse will be gone, already off following their preset schedule (which does not change even when you marry them by the way, they still follow the same routine as they do by default, except when it is interupted by the tasks you can choose to assign them). when you catch up to them...not a single damn mention of the baby they just pushed out. the entire system is barely implemented and it's kind of ridiculous. harvest moon 64 almost 30 years ago had a more robust and interesting system of marriage and children. what they've cobbled together here has the bones of something perfectly adequate, great even, but there is basically no connective tissue to bring it all together. 

overall, the game is quite good for what it is, and despite my negativity there is much to enjoy. but this is a life sim game, and the quite frankly pathetic implementation of some very important systems to the success of a game in that genre - dating, marriage, and children - leave a massive gaping hole in it. fixing these things would not even require a massive revamp of the game. just some basic time and care to make these choices feel as impactful as they should. lockout marriage until a point in the story where it cant create awkward situations, for example. implement new dialogues to accurately reflect relationship changes - despite all the voice acting a significant amount of the dialogue is unvoiced, so it is not even a question of needing to record new lines. just write more dialogue and shove it in there.

review:
it's worth the money. 6/10 rating for now

to sum it up: combat and exploration sucks, but the rest of the game is pretty good and makes up for some of it.

crafting and expanding your workshop is very fun as well as most of the campaign. relationships with the npcs is also good. the town is beautiful.

the bad part is combat, which lacks any kind of challenge and doesn't feel good. you level up your character by doing pretty much anything and this automatically increases your damage significantly. this meant that once i started the first combat oriented mission of the campaign, i was already 10 levels above the enemies and it felt very boring. aside that, i think the main issue is that combat feels very floaty and has no weight. the sound effects animations when hitting enemies are lackluster, making it feel very boring to hit enemies.

stages for exploration are very repetitive copy paste of enviroments and lack any true interesting parts or puzzles.

inventory management is also another small issue, since there's tons of different items, it gets hard to organize them all, specially playing on controller.

overall it's a pretty decent game, with much potential if they fix combat and level scaling.
