review:
let's just get the important bit out of the way first: this is my 2023 game of the year. it was only a matter of when the game would come out of early access to claim its crown. since this game hit on nov. 2, i nominated it for the steam award.

now then, on to why this game is, as of this writing, my 6th most-played title in terms of hours on my steam account.

it's basically everything from my time at portia, but improved upon and made better in every possible way. the world is bigger, the building mechanics refined to a visible-from-space shine, the action rpg story fleshed out in a way that makes it the primary driver of gameplay rather than purely a framing device.

indeed, this is less a cozy game with action-rpg elements and more a reimagining of the action rpg formula where cozy game mechanics are the primary driver of progression. the genres blend seamlessly in a way that they never have before‚Äîlooking at you, horizon zero dawn and forbidden west and every ubisoft game, where the crafting is tedious and feels unnecessary.

but at the same time, this game also has a cozy soul. if you're played any harvest moon-like, the life sim elements are exactly what you want them to be and then some. building relationships with villagers, romance, family life, it's all there with plenty of choices and some remarkably well-written relationship and character backstory dialogue. there are just so many ways to get a villager's friendship up compared to, say, stardew valley's more traditional talk-and-gift approach, and with the anti-frustration feature of not having to talk to every villager every day just to keep their relationship level from backsliding.

speaking of anti-frustration features, there are plenty more in this game as well. none of the main story quests are timed; complete them at your leisure. get overleveled if the combat's not your strong suit. rush the main story quests to unlock more of the crafting recipes if that's your jam. speedrunners and challenge runners? go to town, the game's got plenty of measurable ways to keep score. 

almost none of the sidequests are timed. if you unlock them too fast, as happens when you're powering through the main quest and hitting every character's sidequest trigger faster than you can bang them out, well, take a step back and take your time. the devs listened to players during the early access stage of the process and took the most common frustration‚Äîplayers felt rushed‚Äîout of the game. you want to complete them as fast as possible, nothing's stopping you. but it all fits in with the overarching theme of well-camouflaged accessibility that never feels like it's being dumbed down.

as for the action and combat in the action rpg, well, the devs know they're not from software. this isn't going to challenge anyone with a firm grounding in action games. you can overpower just about anything in the game because the devs have consciously avoided the bethesda syndrome of level-scaling enemies. well, with one exception‚Äîgoing too far afield in a sandstorm is going to surprise you the first time you run into high-level versions of basic enemies‚Äîbut even that is a smart stylistic choice that makes sandstorms feel appropriately dangerous and threatening for a game set against the backdrop of a desert environment with a strong "green aesop" running through the main story.

is the game perfect? well, no, no game is perfect, not even games that are otherwise among the greatest of all time (i say this as someone who loved everything about red dead redemption 2 except for the on-rails quest design, for example.)

for one thing, the fishing minigame is one of the weakest i've seen in this genre. it's simplistic and repetitive and offers almost no challenge and very little reason to even engage with it beyond a couple of cooking recipes. this is a shame, especially since portia's fishing minigame was quite fun and other games like stardew, animal crossing (and dinkum, which cribs heavily from it), and even red dead 2 have great outdoorsman-style fishing gameplay.

in addition, there are a couple of dungeons in the midgame that have a jarring tonal shift toward platformer gameplay. thankfully the devs refined it a bit after its initial introduction; jumps are more forgiving, there's plenty of "coyote time" with ledges, and there's the option to skip the trickiest segments if you fail them enough times, but for a game that otherwise has good dungeon design, there's a heavy "why, devs?" when playing the two dungeons in question.

but those are minor quibbles in a game that is otherwise the absolute apex of the cozy game genre with one heck of a story rpg to go with it.

absolutely, by miles, my 2023 game of the year. 10/10.

review:
in the last week i've played this game for 80 hours. so i like it. just a a little.
my sister bought me this since she'd played the beta. normally i'm not the most excited to play life sims with farming in it because the market is oversaturated with samey, boring games that wish they could be like stardew valley.
instead, i got a game where i don't have to farm if i don't want to (except for some quests but. no daily watering anyway, so that's dope). the story itself has been super enjoyable, and fun. i didn't think it'd ramp up like it did, but serious, emotional moments would pop up out of nowhere, and it felt like such a treat. i can do basically anything, and at my own pace. there's very little the game stopped me from doing that wasn't story related. it's fun to have all the options in the world, and have none of them be a bad on.
sandrock has easily become one of my favorite games, and i hope there's more like it and portia in the future.

review:
"my time at portia" was an apparently simple game, and yet it provided a surprisingly deep experience.
after playing for a good while, it's obvious the developers at pathea games took everything they've learned from the project and put it into "my time at sandrock".
this new title has been improved over the original in every way possible: graphics, artstyle, combat, animations, activities, characters, story... the list covers literally every single aspect of the game, and even if there's still some rough edges here and there, they're very minor and don't hinder at all the quality of the product.

the game combines life-style (housing, crafting, resource gathering, bonding with other characters...) with action/adventure gameplay (exploration, rpg elements, dungeons, boss fights...). all the while, the city of sandrock grows and develops over time and as the story goes forward, with your contribution.
there's also a dedicated multiplayer mode, focusing exclusively on everything revolving around managing your workshop (no story progression, unfortunately, but the fact it's there as an option to have fun with friends in a game that doesn't really need multiplayer, is already more than enough).

if you're in for a fun, hopeful, wholesome and pleasant adventure filled with likeable characters in a vibrant, living world that makes you truly feel a part of it, then there's no reasons not to give this game a try. 
you'll be genuinely suprised by seeing how much care, affection and attention to details have been put into crafting this little gem and what it has to offer.
the part where you're a builder, tasked with gathering resources and building things is truly just part of the tip of a huge iceberg.

even at full price, it's well worth the money.

review:
this is a tremendously satisfying game about harvesting materials, crafting, completing tasks, and helping a town prosper.  it's easy to see just a few hours in just how much thought has gone into the systems.  there's plenty to do to fill a day, and new main and side quests pop up on the regular to keep you moving forward.  the game respects your time with convenient tooltips, tutorials, and things like paying to expand your bags directly from your inventory, or being able to complete objectives with materials in your storage.

the social aspect of the game is also surprisingly strong.  the characters are often interesting and the writing is genuinely funny.  there's an interplay of story and gameplay as certain events will cause prices of goods to fluctuate or prompt a community response.  there are mini-activities to do with townsfolk to increase affinity and neat holidays.  there's also lore bits here and there that i did not expect to be as poignant as they are. 

there is combat, and it is fine, but i do not think that is the main draw.  my only complaints would be nitpicks.  the random character customization produces some nightmarish results, and the house expansion system is somewhat fiddly.  

this is a strong recommend.

review:
as someone who has played their fair share of life simulation games, with the variety of animal crossing, stardew valley, and palia to be some of the main ones, this game comes very close to beating them all. i was thrilled to find out that this game was going to have multiplayer in it, seeing as my time at portia does not have multiplayer, which heavily influenced my choice to buy it or not.

      this game can be buggy at times and while i only have a 980 gpu, i can run this game at medium settings and it still looks pretty decent. i did not play the early access, only full release, and i can say that there seems to be quite a bit of content to this game. this game is very multifaceted with social/town, farming, combat, mining, building, animal, and pet aspects, with that just being what i have discovered with 19 hours of playing. i play with 2 other people and the game runs fairly well. i have only encountered a few lag/server sync issues between other players, a few ui glitch errors, and 1 wonky combat fight with an elite. but beyond those few things i haven't seen much to stop me from wanting to play this game as much as possible. 


[h3] pros [/h3]
- lots of content (19 hours in and it feels like i have so much more to do)
- decent price (i was gifted the game but seeing the price for how fun this game is seems fair)
- fun with friends
- multiplayer actual works
- leveling up feels important and good
- missions feel good and not like leg work (you can visually see the work you put into the town)
- tons of townspeople
- combat feels good and fun
- character customization (you can super customize your character with sliders)
- gear (weapons and clothes have stats that can help you with gathering and fighting)
- weather (the weather events in this game are really great. so far i have seen rain, sandstorm, and summer 
   heat. i am waiting to see snow in this game as of yet.)
- server stays up (no matter who owns the town, i am able to play on my friends server even after the 
   person who made it has left. this is a big game changer for me seeing as you don't have to stop playing on 
   one server because the host has left or crashed.)

[h3] cons [/h3]

- desync/stutter issues (i have only had this happen 2-3 times playing so far and it is fixed by a simple return 
  to lobby and rejoin.)
- ui machine icons disappear (i have only seen this once and it was fixed by rejoining the lobby)
- forced personal chests (i mention this because it was a pain to have only so much room in the one 
   community chest you get at the start of the game. you can upgrade it, but i would like to have the option 
   to share my personal chest contents if i choose to. and not have to run back to home every time someone 
   needed something.
- combat (could use a little work on hit registration and how your character can go through the enemies 
   while swinging your weapon)
- accidental playable character requests (in the game there is an option to talk to real people and play a 
   mini-game called critters. it feels a bit annoying at times when you are trying to interact with machines or 
   doors and other playable characters get the input over the item/machine/door. could be quite annoying if 
   playing with a lot of people in one area but not too bad overall.)

overall this game feels pretty fun to play and in just 2 days my friends and i have put in almost 20 hours each.

review:
this is one of the best life simulator games i have ever played, hands down! it does have a few minor problems but they're barely notable and the pros here far outweigh any cons.

what i think...

+ pros +
++++++++
+ beautiful visuals and characters
+ astounding game mechanics
+ tons and i do mean tons to do for hours on end
+ awesome crafting system
+ awesome building/upgrade system
+ easy to understand and play
+ challenging enemies
+ lots of quests and side missions
+ mail system that actually makes sense and lets you respond
+ town news that makes sense, you can subscribe to get updates on things happening in town
+ finally, a town that feels and looks legit, lots of stores, an arcade, and more
+ lots of mini games and events
+ lots of glorious cutscenes
+ feels very realistic in a lot of ways
+ gameplay draws you in a lot
+ lots of collectibles
+ lots of areas
+ singleplayer and multiplayer
+ lots of replay value


- cons -
----------
- can start to feel rather mundane and repetitive doing the same thing over and over at times
- multiplayer starts of with no house and a lot of missing buildings, this makes absolutely no sense
- controls in multiplayer are by default different than singleplayer, this too makes absolutely no sense
- player water tower to refill with water should have a visual meter to indicate water in it since it's extremely annoying just to have to open it up to check ever time and that makes it difficult to know if you're running low or not while busy with other town commisions and such. a simple visual meter on the side of the tank would make life so much better.
- a lot of the pop-ups such as hints/tips from quests and wandering around show up during cutscenes and can easily be missed as they don't stay there long so you might miss something important and thats very frustating


= verdict =
==========
= my time at sandrock takes everything about the first game and makes it even better plus a little more! there is literally so much detail and realism packed into this wonderful stylized game to keep you busy with the game for hours on end and when you think it stops no it doesn't you can take things on again pretty much through continued multiplayer! its a wonderful game with so many great gameplay machanics and you'll never want to put it down! i highly recommend it! i really hope to see this game come to android as well like the first one did! i would buy it on mobile in a heartbeat! thanks devs for making this amazing game!

review:
this game deserves more attention! although my time at portia was a rough-edged gem that i still enjoyed quite a lot, sandrock greatly improves on its predecessor in almost every way. the town and characters are brimming with personality, the story is great, the quests feel meaningful, and overall the game just feels good to play. the quality-of-life improvements over the original are significant, especially regarding storage. combat still isn't perfect, though it's significantly better this time around. there is just so much to do in this game, and the loop is very addictive and fun!

if you never played portia, it's a bit hard to describe this game. it's not a "farming game", although you can do a bit of that. rather, you are a builder. you salvage, mine, gather, and refine materials, and use those to make and build whatever the town's inhabitants request. there is a heavy focus on characters, relationships, and story, in addition to the surprisingly interesting crafting system. the requests and commissions range from small items, to pieces of furniture, to useful structures that actually get placed permanently in the environment. you, your home (inside and out), and your yard are all highly customizable. almost everything you wear actually shows on your character, too, which is pretty neat!

the desert setting is more than just a backdrop, too. farming is a challenge. sandstorms are a threat. in order to keep your crafting machines running smoothly, you must keep them fueled, clean of sand, and cooled with water. collection and conservation of water is important in this game, not only as a theme, but also in practice. it should be tedious, but somehow it's not, i think due to just how well they implemented this "you are living in a desert" theme overall.

the only two negatives i can think of are a bit of lag as things load in when transitioning areas, and the often charmingly-awkward voice acting. neither of these are enough to even dampen my experience, though. i truly hope this is only the second in a long series of my time games!

review:
i love this game, its chill, its non-punishing, its stress free, its just a really charming and sweet game. i liked portia as well, but never spent nearly the amount of hours i did in this game. i still haven't even finished the story. 

the devs really did a wonderful job improving upon the previous game's mechanics, making a lot of qol improvements that just make the game that much more relaxing and enjoyable. the art is clean and adorable, and the characters are very well done, just like they were in the previous game. i can't stop myself from coming back to these lovable idiots, and i mean that in the most endearing way possible. :d

if you like life sim games, this game has a bit of everything, some farming mechanics, a very basic fishing system that's not your traditional fishing minigame, but its easy and doesn't feel burdensome or required. i love the transmog system the devs have added to allow outfit customization of the character, so you don't have to worry about stats over looks. 

well done, pathea games, well done! thanks for giving us a fun escape from the troubles of life with such a charming and beautiful world.

review:
this sequal to my time at portia happens to be as good as, if not better than my time at portia.
the game has tons of improvements, tons of new features and mechanics, tons of quality of life additions, and more that were not in my time at portia.
furthermore it has a much more detailed and exquisite crafting system, farming system, construction system, and combat system, all of which is easy to learn because it wasn't made very complex.
there is also tons of in game tutorials and means to look back at past information, so the player will not get lost as easily as they did in my time at portia.
this game is a massive improvement in many ways. perhaps the only complaint the player could ever have is water management, and even then, for a player that is willing to learn and understand water conservation, a player will learn how to easily manage their water reserves with time and never run out of water (which will take a long time for people who have extreme difficulty with extremely basic management skills and extremely basic learning skills).
in any case, i have been playing this game since closed beta, i was a kickstarter backer, and i think the full release is infinitely superior to the beta, and it is way better than my time at portia, though it is reasonable to understand that the water management system is treated as the reason many people say this game is worse than my time at portia... it is probably the only downside to this game.
everything else is an improvement. if you love the idea of playing a game where you live in a post-apocalyptic desert wasteland and are actively working towards rebuilding civilization and restoring the environment to a pristine green condition and don't mind the occasional combat scenario this game is for you.

review:
an excellent game.

i took a chance on it during ea since it was nothing like the typical game i would play, (survival, mmos, shooters, etc.) and totally loved it.

the cartooniness can be misleading, it's actually quite a complex game, sort of a mashup of a rpg, singleplayer open world, farming/builder game with interesting npcs and relationships with them.

i see some power-gamer's whining about not having enough stamina to mine the entire world in a day, but they simply have not learned how to play yet.

the key to pacing your game play is based on how quickly you advance the main story quest line. meaning slow down!
if you want to mine more, build, explore, talk to npcs, and feel like you need to catch up, simply don't do the main story quests for a few days, or as long as you want. you control it completely. do not rush the main story quests.

power gamers have to rush everything. this is not that type of experience. slow down and enjoy the journey.

it's a good game, runs smooth, story's about as good as a chinese company can make and then half-bake into english. gameplay loop is satisfying as well, with either farming and gathering or combat, crafting, building. the world is... well, about as nice as a desert can be, and you can make it a bit less... desert-y by decorating, at least your plot of land, your house, your farms. character customization is..... decent. base models are expandable enough, plus you can swap out clothes pretty easily, if not a little... grindy, and there's a pretty decent variety as far as things go, nothing groundbreaking but at least nice enough.
however.
we all knew the price was going to hike up a bit on full release, but in addition to that, they waited until after release to drop all the dlc, a very disappointing half-step that the players definitely should have known better about before the game released. if i'd known there was gonna be dlc aafter release, i would have thought twice about even getting it. however, honestly it's still a really solid package, and some dinky cosmetics aren't going to really make or break your gameplay in most cases.
the game is probably a 7/10, it would have been an 8, however i'm not one to take this game's early-access transition dlc hat-trick lightly.
if you like farming and gathering, decorating and just general life-simmery, i would recommend you get it at a discount, it's 40 usd on release but i would get it for 30 at most.

review:
i have played many many games that attempt to fill the itch that these kind of games offer.

the cycle for me is
1. buy new interesting sim, builder, rpg, etc. game.
2. am super into it for a few irl days, maybe 2 weeks tops. (20 hours or so game time) 
3. as game progresses, and become more complex, start to feel like things are a chore.
4. completely forget about game.

for reference- visit my steam library to verify you are into the same types of games as i am.

[b]this is not that. this game captivates my attention, and is truly an interesting experience, with deep features that only grow as you progress. both through the story, and the amazing sandbox.




this game is a 10/10. a true masterpiece 
 my time at portia is a wonderful and beautiful experience, but sandrock elevates everything portia does to the nth degree.
you will not be dissapointed if you are into these kind of games.
i appreciate the work developer pathea games put into this to deliver such an enjoyable gaming experience in this day and age.

review:
what a game....

if you're like me, you probably got roped into this game after finishing stardew valley. probably itching for the same type of chill, farming and building type of vibes.

instead, what i received was a compelling storyline, great voice acting, and extremely likeable and all around unique characters, as well as an ending that left me wanting for more. not going to spoil anything, but the twists in this game keep you hooked for what's to come after every main quest.

beyond that, mtas is one of the few games where you look back at what you've done and felt like you've made an impact. pieces of your work are sprinkled in full view all over the town, and your relationship with npcs reflect that as well. you'll get that sensation that your builder has truly grown into someone remarkable, worthy of their title by the game's end.

sure, the game might have a tad few bugs lying around, even after release, but honestly the fact that the story was good enough to push me through does spell out something for the writing in this game.

i had a bittersweet ending to my time at sandrock. to know that such an amazing journey will come to an end leaves an empty feeling in my heart, and yet, i look forward to the next entry.

cheers!

review:
this game started off so well, really seeming to be portia but better. but the more i play it, the more issues i'm having. i've got a lot of unconnected thoughts, so i'll list the good and bad then put a summary at the botom.

[b]good:[/b]
[list]
[*][b]oustanding character design, personality, and development.[/b]
seriously some of the most lovable npcs in gaming. everyone has a unique and very well developed personality, with their own backstories and character arc.
[*][b]interesting world with a great concept to base the game off of.[/b]
sandrock has a well thought out history, and you have the goal of showing up while it's getting run down and on the decline, and having to turn it around to make it prosper. you do this by building new things to make the town grow, by uncovering lost technology from the old world long destroyed by the day of the calamity, and by fighting off the growing desert.
[*][b]lots to do.[/b]
farm, build, grow your workshop, decorate, connect with the townspeople, play minigames, catch fish, explore ruins, fight monsters etc. you know what to expect from games like this, and this game manages to include a wide variety of content better than most.
[*][b]humour.[/b]
there's a lot of funny jokes, silliness, nice references, and all sorts that will make you smile.
[*][b]coziness.[/b]
the game is so damn pleasant. there's so many issues with it which i'll get to, but despite them all i still found myself having a great time up until towards the end. it's just such a nice world to be in, it's so lovely learning about all the characters and gradually improving the town and your own workshop. it's really nice.
[*][b]immersion.[/b]
bit of a weird one, but this is something this game does well i think. you can get so absorbed and lost in this world. i love games that have the ability to make me forget the real world and just live in this virtual one for a week or two. this game nailed that. the fact i have 130 hours played after only starting 12 days ago shows what i mean, lol.
[/list]


[b]bad:[/b]
[list]
[*][b]performance.[/b]
the game takes a solid 5-10 minutes to load. this is a constant issue. going from one place to another has a very long loading screen, and even when it finishes loading, very few entities have actually loaded. buildings, menus, npcs, and objects all take an extra minute or so to load. sometimes they just don't load at all, and you'll have to restart the game. i've never had so much issues with load times in a game.
[*][b]the game is extremely grindy and tedious.[/b]
i'm 130 hours in and not even made it halfway towards finishing some things. i'm not exaggerating. i'm still not even done with the story, and from what the achievements tell me, neither are 99% of the people playing the game. collecting resources is extremely repetitive and slow, so is crafting, so is befriending people, and fighting, and pretty much every aspect of the game. everything is painfully longwinded and drawn out, taking a ridiculously long time for little payoff.
[*][b]length.[/b]
i'm never one to complain about how long a game is, the more there is to do the happier i am. this game is the one exception to that. all the story points feel so disjointed. it could end at so many points, but it has to add a new twist or an entirely new and unrelated story every time, which adds an extra 30 hours to the game each time. why has the story gone from developing this town, to catching a bandit, to [spoilers]rescuing a rat princess, to fighting in a war[/spoilers]. it strays so so far from the starting point that it's hard to stay interested, and that brings me to my next point.
[*][b]story.[/b]
it starts off so good, but what on earth happened. at some point you need to stop and question if what you're doing makes sense, and this game just doesn't. the game throws plot twist after plot twist at you, without putting much thought into any of them. none of them make sense, none of them are good ideas, it just feels like it's elongating this already immensely long game for no actual benefit.
[*][b]quality.[/b]
the game is very janky, which i personally think is fine for the most part, but it's worth mentioning. combat has you zipping around erratically, you can walk up almost vertical walls, mounts controls awfully, camera movement during dialogue is very strange, every cutscene is broken if there's a sandstorm going on, sandstorms don't actually do anything, there are almost no quality of life features, lots of invisible walls, there's not much attention to detail, and many features of the game feel very barebones. there's a lot more i could mention but this is already too long. the game just feels very much like they set their ambitions higher than they're able to reach. the fact i've got myself softlocked twice, and just downloaded a week 2 update which fixes 90+ bugs says a lot about the game. it just isn't well made.
[*][b]multiplayer[/b]
when this game was announced, it was planned to have multiplayer. not long before the release of the game, they decided to change that, after already receiving backing and early access purchases from people who were promised the game would have multiplayer. the game now has the most barebones and pointless multiplayer you can ask for, with no story or any of what makes the game fun.
[/list]

to summarise, this game has so much potential. it's a lovely idea, with some elements like character development and world building done remarkably well. however, the poor quality of the game, slow detioration of the story, and incredibly monotonous gameplay results in a very mediocre overall experience.

review:
wish i could give a 'not sure' recommendation but...

the game is generally good, the story works well and flows okay for the most part, mechanics make sense, though some aspects will require a look at the in-game help as the first descriptions may not give all the information you need...

with 200 hours at the time of writing, i have 'completed' the game and enjoyed my time in sandrock...

but it's the cosmetic dlcs, available on, or shortly after, release, that total more than one and a half times the price of the base game...  some of the dlcs come in three parts - each one giving a costume for four of the characters (and three addition recolours of the same costume.)  why does it take three dlcs just to give the main npcs a beach outfit each?

it's not enough to turn my opinion negative, but certainly has made it less of a positive one...

tl;dr - good base game, don't bother with the dlcs unless you have that money to spare and don't mind considering it a donation to the developers.

review: it is good

my time at portia was already a step above any other game i've played in the genre, and my time at sandrock takes it even futher.  the story is engaging, the characters are interesting and invest me in their stories, the gameplay is engaging and well balanced; complicated enough to be fun and to have stuff for my numbers-brain to dig into but without feeling like i need to track a spreadsheet to be good at it.  the changes to inventory management from portia are a huge qol improvement, and the pacing of quests and resource unlocks is also much smoother.

if you've enjoyed stardew valley but haven't tried any of pathea's offerings, it's hard to go wrong here.

review:
tldr; buy it if you love relaxing exploration, farming, or similar kinda casual games. the dialog is fun, the missions seem endless so far but you have no rush to complete most of them. even the timed quests give plenty of time to finish imo. almost too mush time if you want an actual challenge. that's not what this game is though. it's fun and and relaxing while having an interesting story to keep you engrossed in the world.
----
i really liked my time at portia and played it a lot when it came out, but kinda fizzled out with interest the more i advanced in that game. i was excited to give my time at sandrock a chance once i heard about it. i waited until the day it officially came out of beta because i didn't want to burn out of content. i bought the entire dlc at the time to help show support and because you can never have enough outfits imo. 

i only ran into 2 issues so far in my 55 hrs of game play. i posted about them in the bug section and i got a prompt response from the devs each time that they were fixing the issue. both are fixed very quickly. i think each time i posted, it was fixed in the next patch which was only a day or 2 since i commented. both were also kinda minor issues that had a work around if you put thought into it. 

if the fact that's it's still kinda fresh out of beta and has a ton of patches, i can honestly say that you won't regret the purchase. i've been burned by beta and fresh out of beta games before. this is not that. like i said above i only ran into 2 issues that were fairly minor and they were fixed asap. i've enjoyed the heck outta this game and can't wait to see more. the casual farming dating sim aspect brought me in and the story has me hooked.

review:
a really fun stardew valley / harvest moon like, with the emphasis being on crafting items. you can sell what you make for profit, or take on commissions from the other denizens of sandrock.

my favourite part about the my time series is that progression is linked with infrastructure you help to build - bus stations for fast travel, bridges to new areas etc. as you advance, you get to watch the town gradually transform.

if you played and enjoyed and my time at portia then you will love this game - it significantly improves on the first game in just about every way.

review:
i can't even really describe why i like this game i just really do. currently sitting at level 49, no idea how close i am to completing the story.
this game feels like what i wanted out of stardew valley. everytime the game seems to calm down and you feel like you'll get bored of the resource farming the game throws some new character/questline/situation/area at your head which encourages you to farm new materials, build new stuff or upgrade existing structures. its an amazing game to kill a few hours after a long day at work to rewind and do dumb stuff.
the only negative thoughts i have about the game are that the max bag capacity of 280 is too small if you are planting a ton of trees/crops as well. food items don't restore enough stamina to make it worth cooking and that i cannot invest or upgrade the "by the stairs" shop so the shopowner has more then 2000 gols.
i love the monthy python reference or snowwhite's with ged or the mobile suit's. probably missed a few as well.
the resource grinding and sometimes slower days might be the only thing stopping players from enjoying this game. the combat system could use some overhaul as well, haven't really tried out the building aspect of your own home but will do that as soon as i have some more space to relocated animal farms and crops.

review:
i recommend this as a fan of my time at portia. certain failings from the original have been analyzed and resolved in this newest addition to the "my time" series. the game has a huge dynamic cast with lots of fun ways to interact with the villagers, the game is very pretty and the mechanics work smoothly with a few issues now and then from not being close enough to use a tool to things like an npc not allowing you to turn in a side quest(this last one is usually resolved in a few rounds of conversation, though this is mildly frustrating, it may also be an intended feature more than a bug). 

the game takes a fun twist on the normal cozy life sim by placing the player in the role of the towns builder. your goal is to help the townspeople with various tasks whilst also helping sandrock to grow back in to the prospering metropolis it once was. with fun twists to the story, amazing town events, smooth combat and a huge range of items to build and customize i am sure this will be a hit for anyone who enjoys life sims and doesn't mind that they won't be as much of a farmer. i would def put this in a category for coziest game of the year

review:
i enjoyed this game so much that i set the days to take the longest time possible and it took me over 100 hours to get through the first year. this allowed me to enjoy the story rich game for a lot longer and develop relationships in game better.

i am a long time fan of games of this genre but what sets this game apart from all the others for me is how beatifically voice acted this game is, it helped to make the characters feel more alive compared to the usual text boxes, choices you make with your choices of text also impact what the characters reaction are which also helped me to feel more involved with the story. this alongside the beautiful 3d graphics has made this one of my favourite games in this genre so far.


if you are a fan of this genre than i highly recommend giving my time at sandrock a go. 

10/10 would play again

review:
my game of the year. does it lack things from portia that should have stayed the same? yes. does it improve on things since portia? yes. 
should they have included multiplayer instead of focusing on another quality single player game? no. 
are they sadly making a mobile game for the next installation. yes and booooo.
if you loved portia, you will love sandrock hands down. it's a formula they should stick with. it's got the cozy life sim, but you're more of a hero and there's some action/adventure elements. this is not another farm sim. it's in it's own category for me. 
downsides are the factory is now terrible - they plan to fix it.
building system isn't great (your house etc.). 
quests often overlap - sometimes with meetings and holidays, making you miss out on something. -again, they are working on this.
voice actors for surprise characters are horrendous. (english)
some things feel unfinished. (i.e. taking commissions for corps with no increase in rank)
multiplayer - took away from development in what they are good at imo. should have left it out.

upside is, more of the same formula. build, commissions, a battle, story, references new ways to play, new people to get to know, etc.

buy it! and if you haven't played portia - buy that too.

review:
this game is basically a form of animal crossing indie derivative, but its fully voiced and well fleshed out. 
much like animal crossing, its a perfect zen game for just casual vibing. it's not particularly challenging so its perfect for all ages, arthritis hands or young kiddie hands. just about anyone can play this game and enjoy it, (granted, you got to be proactively thinking to optimally succeed).

the devs clearly love this game, and they plan to have post launch support well into 2024. 

apparently, they have a older game similar to this one called "my time in portia" which is actually another city in the same world they created. so each game likely has some story overlap and easter eggs with each other.  so if this game is striking to you, consider also trying portia.

review:
[i]my time at portia[/i] was a real surprise for me when i first played it. i'm pretty sure i got it in a bundle. it looked like someone had repurposed the assets of a korean mmo from 2010. but it turned out to be an unexpectedly feature rich game with an interesting post-apocalyptic worldbuilding, gameplay with genuinely novel ideas in combining the day-to-day work cycle and socializing of [i]harvest moon[/i] with softer factory game mechanics and combat, and just a good amount of content that was fun despite the jank.

[i]my time at sandrock[/i] takes all the good ideas of its predecessor which felt accidentally good at many times, and elevates them so you can make no mistake that pathea are actually a really talented and hardworking company that knows what they're doing. is it free of jank? no, not really. but it's so chockful of good things that even the jank becomes charming. it has a great, interesting story full of characters with vibrant personalities and not the paper-thin cutouts you get in [i]stardew valley[/i]. the world of the setting is so fully realized despite the series' cartoony nature and you feel excited to explore and learn about it. it is genuinely laugh out loud funny at many points, and genuinely emotional at others. i have to give it up for the vas who don't seem like professionals but are still giving their best. the building gameplay while its core loop is the same, sees a lot of qol improvements. the combat is more dynamic and offers a bit of challenge though it's still on the casual side. there's so many small charming details too, like when you go on dates in-game, they put in an animation where your significant other holds your hand. they didn't have to do that. it has no mechanical value. it's just cute and it makes you feel good.

stuff like that is why i think most of all, what the game nails is that it makes it good to be in sandrock, and to see sandrock grow. everyone who plays games for long enough understands the feeling where a place in a game becomes like a real place we have visited and been in, and we feel a sort of nostalgia seeing it. i think sandrock will feel that way to many people playing the game, it's such a wonderfully crafted setting, and it really fulfills the promise of the genre of "life sim" where you can take a break from reality and live somewhere else for a little while. i'm not even done with the main story. i restarted with 1.0 to experience it as intended since in beta lots of the quests squished together in buggy ways as they were implemented, but i feel glad to have done that. this is gonna be a game i will have good memories of and consider a favorite years from now.

p.s. just to be clear, i'm only really reviewing the single-player experience. i have not tried and am not that fussed about multiplayer.

review:
as massive fan of portia, bought this one first day of ea and played it from time to time at various states of it's beta.
at ea launch game had terrible loading time and optimisation issues and since then devs went miles to improve it, up to the point it works smoothly like portia while being massively above it terms of graphics and stuff.

compared with mtap the game feels better in every possible direction, devs listened to their playerbase and adapted the game as much as possible and so far it's one of the best "life sim" games on market, easily equal to legendary stardew valley itself.

if you liked the first game - rest assured, it's "the same but better". much better.
so better that paying full price feels not enough assuming the amount of effort and love devs put into this game.
heavily recommending to any fan of the genre. good stuff.

review:
psa: if you want to play both portia and sandrock, play portia first! the added qol in sandrock makes backtracking to that game somewhat difficult.

the "my time at..." series is something truly special. i picked this one up on a sale iirc, back when the story ended with the destruction of the water tower, so i¬¥ve had this game for a while now. kept starting over every time they added a new big feature and am pumped to finally play the full version, as soon as my  unbelievably slow internet connection is finally done downloading.

is this a good game? heck yeah. i can¬¥t remember how many times i only wanted to finish that one request or finish building that one machine and ended up playing until 4am. the characters are all uniquely loveable, even characters i¬¥d absolutely hate in real life (looking at you, arvio...), the quests will keep you going for a long time and the graphics are that beautiful cozy comic style that makes you believe that everything will be alright in the world.

so buy a train ticket and pick up that pickhammer. sandrock is waiting for you!

one thing i wanted to mention is an accessibility(?) feature. i'm not disabled, so i can't comment on that, but i have carpel instability in both hands which makes a lot of typing and button pressing painful after a long time. so having the auto-run feature is huge to me. god it really saves my life. controller or pc, even holding the joystick will hurt so pc is better with auto run. not many games offer this feature (stardew does not!) so it really helps me out. thanks devs!!!!!!

review: a fun twist on the cozy farming sim genre. my time at sandrock captures the spirit of the cozy farming sim vibe while playing completely differently from other games in the genre like harvest moon, story of seasons or stardew valley. it is more a crafting sim than farming, and the involved building mechanics do have the potential to stress you out if you let it. however, if you are willing to take it at your own pace and not let the perpetually growing quest list pressure you, it can still be a fun and relaxing experience. with the ability to choose how quickly you want time to pass in-game and lots of quality of life improvements from its predecessor, my time at portia, this is a fantastic game for fans of the cozy genre if you are willing to put in the time to overcome the learning curve for its very different gameplay loop. for those like me who play these types of games for the social aspects rather than the actual farming/crafting mechanics, my time at sandrock really delivers with lots of festivals, friendship and relationship quests, including cute little cutscenes that may not serve the plot but do immerse you in the delightful ambiance of sandrock. it's nice to find a cozy game that is not just more of the same.

review:
[h2]ahoy![/h2]

this be ye local piratical reviewer comin' to tell ye if my time at sandrock be worth your precious doubloons or whether she be sent down to the briny depths!

i want to tell ye first, i've played the predecessor my time at portia to completin' and will be makin' some comparisons between 'em, i'll also be splittin' me thoughts into ayes 'n nays for easy readin'

[h3]ayes[/h3]

[b]a real sense o' progression[/b]
my time at sandrock (mtas) nails that sense of progression that my time at portia (mtap) pioneered. as ye be making ye adventures, ye'll be changing sandrock, from buildin' cranes te' fixing the hydrogel, expanding the yakmel network to more serious ventures like plantin' forests in the desert and building the road to portia. 

for each quest chain ye complete, you'll get reminders just how far ye've came. making ye feel apart of the world, and ultimately it's my most favourite draw to mtas.

[b]craftin'[/b]
goin' hand in hand with makin' ye changes in sandrock, the crafting is an improvement upon mtap. ye have a bounty o' machines to be gettin' ye buildin. most days ye'll be havin' machines runnin' all day pumpin out manner o things for ye designs. ingots, screws, slabs, everything to be gettin' everythin' built. occasionally, you'll feel overwhelmed but honestly, i felt that it feed it the hectic job that is bein' a builder in mtas. ye'll eventually condense this into ye crown jewel near the end, the almighty factory.

[b]exploration[/b]
the world of sandrock is huge and thar be plenty to see and dive. you'll be prowlin' through dangerous ruins, fighting robots and mobs for parts ye need for your builds and ye'll be spendin' a fair chunk o' ye time in the abandoned ruins, bringin' up various ores and relics to both smelt and reassemble. i've got no complaints.

[b]the characters[/b]
in this pirates honest opinions, the characters in mtas shine far brighter then those in portia. every character has a small chain that details there daily lives and a insight to their personality. it added that depth to life and some reason to care about the characters compared to portia, the massively expanded amount of quests featured in mtas, really helped in this situation.

[h3]nays[/h3]

[b]combat[/b]
thar has been a' few changes to combat, however, it still be simplistic. you'll be finding yourself usin' the same strategies ye found in portia. ye'll be dodging the choreographed events, going in to break' em and then just devastating 'em. it's the same ole' song and dance. it be worse with guns, ye'll whip your pistol o' rifle and just stun lock and break your enemy in place, making short work out most o' everything. disappointin' really.

[b]performance[/b]
this be nay gay breakin' but ye'll certainly notice it in ye adventurin'. mtas doesn't play aswell as portia, ye have pop in galore, especially o' anything ye've added to the world via the quests. the game chugs in the town itself and has random slow downs in various places. it can detract from ye' experience.

the small positive is for me, is that the game has mostly been light on bugs and pathea has been on the ball since release. 

[b]dlc practices[/b]
i hated to be addin' this one but ¬£4.49 for costumes for 4 characters and putting the favourites separate in individual packs is a practice that belongs in davey jones locker. either bundle them together for a tenner or reduce the price of the individuals. currently it looks a cash grab and add as a tarnish to this shining treasure.

[h3]conclusion n' scoring[/h3]
mtas is a large game and it's hard to condense everything inte' a few paragraphs. it's a massive improvement on mtap. if ye loved that game, ye'll be right at home here. a no brainer for ye doubloons.

if ye the kind of sailor that loves a solid sense o' progression with an in-depth crafting system, memorable characters and a massive chain of quests to go on and doesn't mind some minor annoyances and lacklustre combat system. ye'll definitely find some good sailing 'ere.

i give mtas a solid 8.5/10 gold doubloons. a massive improvement over portia if not marred by spotty performance and cheap dlc tactics.

review:
while i will say it may not be for everyone, i think this game is great. its a fun game for when you just want to relax and chill. for the most part, quests can be done at your own pace (there are some timed ones, but they usually give you plenty of time to complete them,) so you can spend your time mining, growing crops, killing monsters, whatever you want, and usually not feel rushed or pressured to progress the story along. the characters are interesting and varied, and the voice acting is good.

of everything, though, i think the music in this game is the best part. i would totally just sit and listen to the soundtrack all day, if i needed something to help relax.

i have hundreds of hours in my time at portia, and for a sequel, this game blew every expectation i had away! solid 10/10 for me.

review:
this game is a sequel to "my time at portia", both storywise and in technical development. i bought this game during its' early access period, and it is one of those rare cases where an early access game turns out well. 

the visuals are bright and colorfull, despite being set in a desert, with both characters and buildings standing out against the desert. 
the soundtrack is thoroughly wild western in character, albeit slightly repetetive after several hours of the same tracks repeating.
storywise, the numerous quests are interesting, and the characters have some depth. the game avoids the pitfall of giving all characters similar quests and instead focus on growing the characters themselves.

overall the game is a great game to relax to, with many things to do.

review:
[h1]i liked it.[/h1]
i liked portia, and i liked this game. just finished it! lots to do, the story is much more significant than i expected. thumbs up.

...with caveats. i had hoped that this time around we'd be able to avoid some of the pitfalls that portia had, and there were exotic new pitfalls to enjoy as well.

[h2]spoilers ahead, sorry. skip to conclusion for non-spoilery assessment[/h2]

[h3]the good[/h3]
[list]
[*]unsuur
[*]lots of story content, more than portia
[*]you get to feel epic as the townies come to respect you
[*]the civil corps of sandrock acknowledges you as an honorary member instead of pretending for the entire game that they are stronger than you in spite of your combat prowess like the civil corps of portia did
[*]didn't rely pretty much at all on any of the old workshop machines from the old game, and new models where there was overlap
[*]had a much more effective environmental message, where portia kind of deliberately put you at odds with the environmentalists in the game while trying to talk about the importance of environmentalism
[*]some (some) of the voice acting was pretty good
[*]i liked the weapon variety and specialization you could do through knowledge points
[*]did a decent job of making it so you could stop hunting for older, low-level ore and minerals while still making you track down new ores and occasional rarities like engines and stuff.
[*]datable men in this game are way hotter than in portia. so are the women, but the glow-up award goes to the guys. much better fleshed out personalities across the board too.
[*]i really liked hanging out and dating being instant instead of scheduled for a specific time the next day.
[/list]

[h3]the bad[/h3]
[list]
[*]arvio
[*]nearly every model that's not a permanent feature of the landscape takes a long time to load in
[*]quite a bit of the voice acting and sound design is somewhere between questionable and bad
[*]pacing is often weird. see section below.
[*]dating and hanging out still isn't fun
[*]there is no contest whatsoever in the builder rankings. i beat yan in year one without trouble, and in year two mi-an didn't come close. i could have done just one commission a day and i still would have been miles ahead. i expected mi-an to surge ahead to at least claim some yan-level numbers once yan wasn't taking credit for all her work, but she just wasn't remotely a threat.
[*]there was not nearly enough variety in the commissions. never-ending metal ingots, metal plates, stone slabs, petrified wood planks and sticks, and canvas were my reward for climbing to five stars. why aren't people commissioning more, you know... built stuff?
[*]what the hell happened to the factory? in portia it had an awesome animated interior and dedicated upgrade options. in sandrock it's an ugly living room with all your machines crammed into it as cramped as you can manage. in portia it worked with the automated half of your assembly station, but in sandrock you wish you could just delete your assembly station entirely because you'll never use it again.
[*]i never once used a powerstone of either grade. i found it impossible to run out of dregs.
[*]i love merle, but i wanted a goat with rambo's horns.
[*]there's a whole upgrade in the abandoned ruins goggles to let you see the outline of the items you scan. only problem is every scannable item is smaller than the diamond indicator so you'll never actually see the outline of anything. portia had no such issue.
[*]sandrock fails in multiple instances to teach you about functions of the game. i never once learned to use a camera, so i had a whopping zero photos at the end of the game. i was made aware of the existence of parties thanks to the resources i had to make them go over well, but i only learned from the end credits that i was supposed to purchase and set up a banquet table to unlock this feature. i discovered that many of the datable npcs have outfit options in the social menu. i never found out how to make those happen. the fashion show seemed like the time for that to unlock, but the outfits were never made purchaseable, despite barber guy's enthusiasm about selling them in his dialogue. i thought maybe it was dlc, but it turns out it's not, so how was that meant to unlock? maybe after you marry them? nope. still no idea.
[*]i gave grace a custom pet name to call me when we got married. she just called me sugar instead.
[*]i am genuinely unsure if there are enough small items to donate to the museum to successfully fill the small item slots available
[*]the house builder interface is janky as hell. sometimes you just have to quit and go back in to get anything done as various items refuse to bring up their interaction options, become unmovable, become unresizable, or just plain disappear because of an errant click. was it a workshop machine? then don't bother checking your inventory or the "workshop machine" menu on the builder interface, because it's now in your mailbox. so better get your ass back home to get that item and then head back to the house builder thing to try and remember what you were doing.
[/list]

pacing issues
[list]
[*]i earned a greenhouse before i was ever able to develop a single tile of biocrust naturally, despite nonstop gardening starting the moment gardening was available. even without the greenhouse, the main story gifted me enough biocrust to make generating it manually a pointless feature.
[*]i was excited to get my max-level spear, but i earned the laser sword before i could make one and it was the indisputable optimal choice, rendering my knowledge points in spears worthless
[*]in portia the final build, a plane, blindsides you with a sudden need for truckloads of crystals you never thought to harvest before and makes you take in-game weeks just waiting for them to spawn so you can finish the quest. sandrock's elegant answer to this problem is to make the final build embarrassingly easy to complete. you'll probably have it finished in an afternoon with materials you had laying around. please, by all means, send me on a couple days of fetching to get the parts i need for this once-in-a-game build. they're never going to ask for another one, so make them unique items that i need to fight some boss monsters to obtain or something. i don't know, but "a single expedition's worth of nanomaterial scrap and poplar wood and (checks notes) an item made a tiny amount of copper and bronze" can't possibly be the best answer.
[*]in both portia and sandrock, the factory is a double-edged sword. it feels awesome to unlock godmode in your workshop, but you'll never have to think meaningfully about any commissions or build quests again. that's the day you go from bustling builder to rare material scavenger, and there's no going back, really. it was also too cheap and easy to have a factory in this game. couple grand, you're good to go. at least in portia you had to gather a mess of expensive materials and pony up the cash.
[*]you'll have the max-level workshop equipment by about the halfway point of the game. upgrading feels nice, so it's sad when this goes away so soon.
[/list]

[h3]conclusion[/h3]
this is a fundamentally fun game that, like its predecessor, is deeply flawed. it has heart, but it feels unfinished in a way i know they're not going to fix. i had hoped portia would serve as a learning experience that would lead to sandrock being far more optimized out the gate. instead, it's genuinely unclear if they learned much of anything from portia's issues.

would i buy a new entry in this series in the future? well... probably. because they did at least prove they have some fun new ideas that do iterate successfully on the "my time at" formula. but at this point pathea is cementing itself in my head as a studio with a lot of muscle in the ideas department, but anemic in the polish department. the public is growing weary of studios that can't release a finished game.

review:
i largely enjoyed my time at sandrock, with some big caveats, but for the most part the 40 hours (give or take) i spent with the game were quite positive!

the game keeps you pretty busy throughout by pouring the objectives and big milestones on you. i always felt like i was chasing some far away goal and always had stuff to do and people to talk to. there's no shortage of content here, and even though i stopped at the 40 hr mark, i could have easily done another 40 with the amount on offer. 
the social system is great. it's a grind, but it's great. you can go on dates with your townspeople and i feel like the dates are actually thoughtful - you don't just ply them with gifts and everything works out - you have to plan what you want to do according to what the npc likes to do.

i loved the setting - it's such a unique setting for a life sim and it actually plays directly into the game play. it isn't just lip service. the town relies on a meagre supply of water and it *isn't* freely available so you have to plan everything around having a supply of water to power your machines. they even add layers of complexity later on as story twists put a real squeeze on the towns water supply. that's really cool. you also can't just fell every tree in sight as the environs rely on them to maintain water. so you are really scavenging from wrecks and debris and it lends the game this real desert junkyard vibe that i think works well. 

on the flipside, though, i find the art style, characterisation and dialogue a lot more cringey than in other management/life sim games. i get that a lot of these games are meant to be wholesome and kindly, it's a big part of why the genre has the appeal it has, but it doesn't work here. in stardew valley, it's wholesome but genuine. here in sandrock, everything is sickly sweet. people treat you with fawning praise that comes off as either blindly naive or painful disingenuous and as a result, i didn't really feel totally connected to any of the characters as much as i did in, say, spiritfarer, which in terms of characterisation is best in class. so that sucks, because *quite* a lot of the game is spent talking to people. and it's a lot. a lot. of really cheesey cringey dialogue. 

this game is also afflicted with the baggage of the genre: grinding. i really feel like the end game *has* to involve some kind of automation because there's only so much joy that can be wrung from grinding for resources and plying them into machines and manually making *everything* every single time. at the start, this is a genuinely fun pursuit as you always have goals to aim for, but the pursuit soon becomes your cage and before you know it, the game is playing you when it should be the other way around.

generally speaking, despite these negatives, i feel like sandrock is a great time if you know what you're getting into, but a lot of the genre's contemporaries have done this before, and maybe even better.

review:
this game has been honestly really enjoyable overall. i played it on the early access at first and then put the game down until release and i'm impressed by the amount of content it has now compared to when i first tried it out. i really enjoy all the building, crafting, gathering etc. 

the game makes me feel like i'm always in a race against time, on the clock tick tock gotta go fast, but after a while i realized it really dsnt matter if you just chill out and take your time. missing some of the daily missions is perfectly fine and just exploring at your own pace is not a problem at all. of course, the nature of the daily cycle mixed with the daily contracts adds this feeling of being in a rush to do everything you can do within a single day. 

the combat and gearing is very simple but its still a part of the game i did enjoy. don't expect like difficult combat, but its still satisfying to see my damage grow as i get levels and upgrade my gear to purple + highest item level in the machines.

i hit max character level and max level workshop in multiplayer and i still have places to explore, missions to complete and new things to craft/build.

fantastic game, especially at the price.  great characters (with really well done vo), fun story with a few twists, tons to do, and oozes charm.  

it's not without warts - the combat is still pretty basic, and it's incredibly easy.  that doesn't detract from this game since it's a nice, chill experience regardless, but i do think their next game in the series could do with a difficulty slider.  

graphically, it's cute but nothing to write home about, and while the parts of the world that have stuff going on are very vibrant and engaging, there's still a ton of empty space.  while that kind of fits the setting, it's still a bit offputting.

overall, highly recommend if you're looking for a stardew valley/rune factory/etc. type experience that you can really sink into.  it will also make you smile and laugh out loud more than you think it should.

review:
my time at sandrock is a delightful blend of farming, crafting, and exploration that surpasses its predecessor. the desert setting is visually stunning, with vibrant landscapes and dynamic day-night cycles.

gameplay improvements shine in the expanded farming and crafting systems, providing a satisfying balance. the revamped relationship mechanics add depth to character interactions, with compelling story arcs enhancing the overall narrative.

exploration is a highlight, with dungeons and hidden treasures adding excitement to the vast desert world. the graphics and sound design create an immersive atmosphere, contributing to a relaxing gaming experience.

despite minor bugs, the developers' commitment to updates is evident. my time at sandrock is a must-play for fans of the genre, offering a rich and engaging escape into a beautifully crafted oasis.

review:
a worthy, quality sequel. ‚Äúmy time at portia‚Äù was a decent game, but ‚Äúmy time at sandrock‚Äù takes nearly all the ideas to the next level, making it hard to go back to the previous game.

the game does a good job of combining lore and gameplay elements, which is quite unusual and pleasant for the genre. thanks to the fact that the player has a goal from the very beginning, and the set of actions is mostly based on how the world is structured, the game feels cohesive. for example, the ability to plant crops is not just given because it‚Äôs necessary, but due to certain plot events, and it‚Äôs given by an npc. the process of growing plants, although a bit tedious and requires excessive micromanagement, is still justified by the game world: water is scarce, the soil isn‚Äôt the best, so you have to put in the effort.

there‚Äôs a lot of content in the game, it unfolds quite slowly, but that‚Äôs not a downside, because there‚Äôs always something for the player to do. both the main quest and all the side quests may not be tarantino-level in terms of execution, but they‚Äôre adequately composed, always capable of keeping the game interesting.

the game has a few downsides:

[olist]
[*]clunky controls coupled with a rather primitive camera behavior. for example, you need to press a separate button for aiming, after which the camera sensitivity seems to increase due to the change in the camera‚Äôs anchor point.
[*]extremely sparse, quite primitive animation. it reveals the budget nature of the project and hinders immersion.
[*]an excess of invisible walls, especially in the local dungeons. it feels like the authors set up the walls after prototyping the levels, but forgot to put up boxes and other obstacles blocking the path in some places or placed them too far away.
[*]useless multiplayer. there is a cooperative mode in name, but it‚Äôs very primitive and boring. the authors chose an earlier time period of the city when it was under construction, were too lazy to attach a decent plot, and just allowed several players to mess around in it at the same time.
[/olist]

overall, my time at sandrock is a worthy representative of the sandbox genre. the gameplay, except for the combat component, is decent, the plot is also decent, the graphics are decent, albeit with a specific stylization. against the backdrop of glitchy, unfinished games, this one looks pretty good.

review:
one of the best romance mechanics ever. it might be worth buying this game for that alone... but you have to keep in mind that the game is rough around the edges. and some of these edges are really, really rough.

the story is great. i don't care if you saw the twists coming; it is the *telling* of the story that was done well. character designs improved massively, especially for bachelor npcs. voices range from excellent to decent to what-happened-to-your-microphone.

some characters are really good. some are really bad. some i would be okay leaving to hungry wolves. if there was a button to eliminate mi-an i would press that button with zero hesitation; embarrassingly poor characterization of a rival type that otherwise would have had so much potential. i gave her venom every day just so we wouldn't be buddies. on paper, at least. mi-an does not respect your boundaries on that regard.

there are a lot of weird animations in this game. weird facial expression. weird cock-eyed npcs. but it's really still a good game. music is a treat. i find myself humming the seasonal themes. romance in here is one of the greats; i hope this will remain their forte in future games.

maybe buy on discount if bugs will frustrate you. just play this game to the end at least once.

review:
my time at sandrock is a charming, cozy and relaxing game with an intriguing storyline, a diverse and lovable cast of characters, and an addictive gameplay progresion loop that sees you and your workshop grow, alongside with the community of sandrock.

the art style, music and excellent writing has made this cozy game into a very immersive experience. i went in not knowing how much of a focus the game had on story, and was very pleasantly surprised at the writing, direction, length and depth of the story and world building.

as a complete game with a satisfying amount of content, this game would easily take about 100+ hours to complete for the average person.

pros:
(+) excellent story line that kept me motivated to see what happens next. a lot of effort has been put into the story and set pieces, more so than similar life sim / farming games.
(+) addictive gameplay progression loop and pacing of progressing through the main story, upgrading your tools and workshop, and making lasting changes to sandrock.
(+) well written characters that you learn a lot about and grow to love / care for through your time with them. characters each have their backstories, motivations and distinctive personalities which contribute to the social feel of sandrock, as well as the narrative.
(+) wide variety of customization options for player character appearance, and workshop (including housing, furniture, plants and decorations).

subjective:
(=) movement feel a bit "weightless"; there is no momentum to movement.
(=) resource gathering may feel grindy at times especially if you try to optimize stamina usage each day, but is over-all well balanced if you pace yourself through daily commissions and exploring the sidequests.
(=) the mini games are very charming, and add a lot to the festivals / events in the game's calendar. however, they may be more simplistic than one would expect.

cons:
(-) several minor bugs at release, personally have yet to experience anything gamebreaking. the devs are actively working on addressing known issues.

overall, an excellent game. i'm very much looking forward to what pathea games has in store next!

review:
this is a hard one to judge. this game is a culmination of both what i love and hate about modern video games.

pros:
* the game loop isn't bad. it's similar to the predecessor and they didn't modify it much from there. 
* the characters in the game are pretty decent and distinct. some of them develop in unexpected ways which is neat.
* there "larger than life" events that do better than what its predecessor had.
* the conveniences later on are better than what was in its predecessor (with unfortunate caveats due to bugs).
* a cozy quality-of-life game.

cons:
* this game is buggy to a point i'm not sure how the hell it was released like it was. some of the bugs are similar to what i saw in early versions of its predecessor game which tells me they didn't learn much from their mistakes in implementation. i've made a list i can remember off the top of my head below.

* the combat is pretty weak. i didn't pay much attention to the early access but i was hoping they'd really make the combat more interesting. make no mistake that it's definitely better than what portia had. there's more variety here but it's literally "smash the x button" when you get down to it.

* after awhile, farming and mining stuff becomes repetitive which thankfully becomes easier. [strike]unfortunately, because the factory has such a fucked up implementation and literally doesn't work half the time, that convenience can be more irritating than helpful.[/strike] there's also no way to farm certain stuff or to get someone else to fetch it like agate. you have to go out and spend 5-10 minutes picking them 2 at a time. this isn't as big of a deal though, you don't generally need agate that often but for example, flourite you do since certain items that show up on commission require it to increase rarity. the only other way to get that is through ruin tokens which is already expensive and time consuming to obtain....

* some commissions are a trap. it might look easy but they want increased rarity on something like a steel bar which requires flourite to create which is an absolute pain in the ass to get. these commissions are never worth the gold they give (and they don't give much generally). they're there to make you feel miserable. the game should give double gold for such requests or triple gold for rare quality items.

all that said... i've already gotten over 100 hours out of it and i'll probably finish it. i'd wait for a sale but i'd be lying if i said i didn't enjoy it. there isn't really any challenge to it which kinda kills it a little bit. you can fail some stuff but you either have to try to fail it or fail it via a bug. 

bugs i saw while playing:
* literally first five minutes into the game, you'll notice that coco the bird fly's sideways and slow as if running into a wall. literally shows in one of the earliest cutscenes as you start playing.

* mobs and npcs end up your workshop seemingly lost, as if their pathing is telling them to go there for some reason and then they just literally run around doing nothing.

* soft locks are brimming in this game. they seem to be worse when you play the game for extended periods of time which brings me to...

* the game has some issues when played for long periods of time. things load slower or not at all, animations are wonkier, sound may not occur at all having you miss actually interesting voice lines.

* [strike]the factory you get later into the game is a broken mess. the ui doesn't update properly, parts of the ui doesn't work with controller for some reason, and multiple times now i've had the recycler "production queue" absolutely busted to where it was unusable. things that should produce more than one of a thing, for example bullets (5 each) or copper screws (2 each), will only produce one which is a clear bug since it shouldn't take fucking 20 steel bars and 50 gunpowder to make literally 10 rifle bullets, but doing the same thing directly on a forge would give you 50.[/strike] this was fixed in latest patch of this writing.

* npcs will fall to the bottom of the map, teleport endlessly, float in the sky or just out of reach, or not be able to interact with them at all until you leave the room or restart the game even.

* npc pathing will often put them smack dab in the middle of a cutscene where they mob pile to the point you can't see anything going on anymore.

* i've softlocked on a lot of scenes that want your character to automatically moved but apparently, i'm alone in this according to the forums.

* i've had the planting grid get stuck in 5x5 when in 4x4 mode, then plant incorrectly. this was with the robot: f machine. edit: there is a 5x5 mode later in the game but the robot isn't supposed to have it. 

* quests not triggering which would then fail after time passes.

* too many events scheduled at once. i had several quests on the same day as the day of memories, all at 1600.  they not only won't reschedule any of them, they also will cause bugs like not letting you join the ghost hunting event.

* probably more i'm not thinking of or too small of a bug to care.
