review:
mtas is, from the get-go, very similar to its predecessor my time at portia and for the most part that holds true as this was supposed to be an expansion before turning into a separate project.

does it separate itself enough to warrant a separate purchase? i believe so, although i believe the price increased since early access when i purchased it.

initially i was put off by the chosen setting as having a farming game be set in a desolate desert setting seemed like a tall order but the developers managed to introduce new mechanics to account for this without removing one of the core parts of the original game. i will not go into detail as some of these mechanics are also tied to the story which is appreciated as well. they may seem a bit tedious at the beginning but eventually as with the previous games most of the energy/water requirements become trivial from simply farming out other resources which i find to be nice as the game is already pretty grindy as its predecessor was in some aspects. a quick tip: do try to get a pet asap as they help a ton.
how grindy the game feels however depends on what you as the player would like to do and how stressed you feel about worker of the month/year nominations. if you want to keep ahead you will be farming 3-4 commissions daily as well as blowing all your stamina in abandoned ruins which can become a bit of a repetitive chore (for me this feeling started somewhere around winter 1st year). in order to avoid this i would recommend engaging with other parts of the game as well (hangouts/romance/building the house/farm) and not feeling like you need to squeeze out every ounce of stamina out of every day otherwise you will burn out quickly.

in terms of the story i still have not reached the complete conclusion but i believe nobody expected this game to bring out a game of the year contender in this regard.
if there is one thing however i would say that the pacing feels off for me. lot of the progression is gated by arbitrary amounts of days that have to pass in order for you to even receive an email that will tell you (at the beginning of a given day) that the story will continue 2 days from now. after those 2 days pass you usually go to a fireside meeting where they will say something usually followed by another day or 2 of waiting which became a real point of frustration as i already blew through all the mining/building content and needed story to progress to access the 3rd abandoned ruins which never seem to come. at this point i am in year 2 spring and i have been done with all that 2nd abandoned ruins offer in year 1 day 26 autumn which means i spent most of winter just running around hoping a side-quest would appear or the story would hurry up and come but it never did as from what i read i am still a few mysterious letters off from actually getting to the ruins. feels like i am being drip fed story at this point which would be fine if i was not done with everything i can do in a given day at about 3pm with plenty of time to spare.

hangouts/romance are pretty similar to what they were in portia but i appreciate the variety of characters that are available although i do miss papa bear. i thought sandy was going to be a nice replacement for papa bear for me but the sound that camel makes evoke some primordial feelings of horror in me so i avoid her usually.
one thing that i find odd is how easy it is to become a bff with heidi specifically since many of the commissions are from her so even if i do not really care about her she is my best friend stat-wise since avoiding her commissions would be hamstringing my progress too much. of course with addition of a bounty board this levels out a bit as those requests (at least in my experience) came from a variety of characters usually not requesting standard commissions like elsie for example who in my play-through appeared on standard commission board maybe twice with a incredibly simple request that yields almost no rewards.

all in all it might seem like i am airing my grievances with the game which is true but i still really like it for what it is. it may not be perfect owing to the points above or the bugs which still plague it but i do believe it is a great experience for people who liked the first game and builds upon it well. the grind feels satisfying when done in moderation and there are a lot of options for customizing your yard and house. romance options are plenty and compared to the first game there seem to be more post-marriage content.
i do hope future brings more bugfixes and even content if we should be so lucky.

p.s.
if a sequel ever comes i do hope for a different environment though as portia was also 1/3 if not 1/2 desert which i understand is a rather major plot point in the overall story but i am kind of over sand now, thanks.

review:
great game. must buy if you liked portia. minor spoilers below.
list of bugs i encountered throughout playing:
- characters get stuck into each other trying to exit a building
- you can climb along the cliff when you get to the "mama tree" and fall down the other side of the cliff of the desert and get stuck
- "into the abyss" mission you get a slow debuff that says 0sec duration but remains throughout the mission so i just spam roll everywhere.
- in the next dungeon after i had a slow and poison debuff of 0 sec that was permanent until i died and reloaded.
- once or twice loading screen didnt work when entering the house so i lost 20-30mins of progress (autosaves saved the day)
- everyone gets handed a medal but mc does a t-pose when receiving the medal
- mc becomes semi/fully transparent/invisible when mounting a horse and then briefly when dismounting.
- mounts and npcs constantly teleport to get to where they need to go so u have to "catch them" via dialogue before they fade with the wind.
- married amirah and her bd party is during one of the festivals so she didnt even attend her own party
- built the sand buggy on the assembly station and it was literally invisible
- was outside the house and my pet was stuck in the walls of my house
- bumble ants like to walk into the walls of my property (bad pathing)
- there are two enemies that no longer spawn due to game progression but civil commissions are still posted asking you to wipe them out.
- there were a couple instances where commissions are posted asking you to create an item using resources that are farmed in an area you dont have access to yet.

list of stuff i didnt like:
- too many relic pieces and i didnt want to spend the time looking/sorting through each storage box to find the duplicates so i would make multiple storage boxes which would have the same duplicate in multiple boxes
- max backpack space is a lot, but was still maxing it out more often than i wanted to as there are items (like gifts) i always kept on hand
- to 100% steam achievements in a reasonable time you need to talk and gift everyone from day 1 as social exp is a big grind otherwise
- weapon perks are unbalanced; why pick a 10% slow/burn/poison chance on hit when u can just go raw crit build with crit dmg, crit chance and lifedrain
- cant keep track of items donated to the museum unless you manually track it on spreadsheet (see guide in forums)
- when npc's steal your kill, you dont have that enemy registered to the bestiary, so if that enemy is a boss enemy that only spawns once, glhf. you also get no exp
- npc's run as fast as a slow horse, but you're stuck with the same runspeed throughout the game (exception is temporary buff in dungeon).
- read in forums automation doesnt give you workshop exp
- animals seemed like an afterthought since those buildings are maxed at lv 1, otherwise is a decent choice for extra side income
- thrown items were meh, and you cant use them to mine ores
- hard to build relationship pts with kids or animals since they dont post commissions so with animals you can only talk and gift once a day, (with kids you can also play critters)
- non essential npc's have nothing better to say other than "..."
- va for musa is also a soldier.

things i did like:
- items from storage can be used to turn in items for quests
- good variety of characters/memorable personalities, but then there's people like jensen who has no backstory
- get to see how your projects build sandrock up, enjoyed the story and how it related to the last game
- ranged weapons are a pretty cheesy way of beating combat content 
- melee combat was good for a game not focused on combat
- enough perks to make more gol, make friends faster, make stuff faster, etc
- steam achievements are not difficult to achieve, but some are somewhat grindy unless you plan ahead. i think roughly 140hrs until i get 100%.
- you can go to options menu to speed up or slow down the game at leisure 0.6-3x so waiting for time related events doesnt take forever.

some bugs but nothing gamebreaking, if fixed then solid 9/10 otherwise 8/10.

review:
this game started off so well, really seeming to be portia but better. but the more i play it, the more issues i'm having. i've got a lot of unconnected thoughts, so i'll list the good and bad then put a summary at the botom.

[b]good:[/b]
[list]
[*][b]oustanding character design, personality, and development.[/b]
seriously some of the most lovable npcs in gaming. everyone has a unique and very well developed personality, with their own backstories and character arc.
[*][b]interesting world with a great concept to base the game off of.[/b]
sandrock has a well thought out history, and you have the goal of showing up while it's getting run down and on the decline, and having to turn it around to make it prosper. you do this by building new things to make the town grow, by uncovering lost technology from the old world long destroyed by the day of the calamity, and by fighting off the growing desert.
[*][b]lots to do.[/b]
farm, build, grow your workshop, decorate, connect with the townspeople, play minigames, catch fish, explore ruins, fight monsters etc. you know what to expect from games like this, and this game manages to include a wide variety of content better than most.
[*][b]humour.[/b]
there's a lot of funny jokes, silliness, nice references, and all sorts that will make you smile.
[*][b]coziness.[/b]
the game is so damn pleasant. there's so many issues with it which i'll get to, but despite them all i still found myself having a great time up until towards the end. it's just such a nice world to be in, it's so lovely learning about all the characters and gradually improving the town and your own workshop. it's really nice.
[*][b]immersion.[/b]
bit of a weird one, but this is something this game does well i think. you can get so absorbed and lost in this world. i love games that have the ability to make me forget the real world and just live in this virtual one for a week or two. this game nailed that. the fact i have 130 hours played after only starting 12 days ago shows what i mean, lol.
[/list]


[b]bad:[/b]
[list]
[*][b]performance.[/b]
the game takes a solid 5-10 minutes to load. this is a constant issue. going from one place to another has a very long loading screen, and even when it finishes loading, very few entities have actually loaded. buildings, menus, npcs, and objects all take an extra minute or so to load. sometimes they just don't load at all, and you'll have to restart the game. i've never had so much issues with load times in a game.
[*][b]the game is extremely grindy and tedious.[/b]
i'm 130 hours in and not even made it halfway towards finishing some things. i'm not exaggerating. i'm still not even done with the story, and from what the achievements tell me, neither are 99% of the people playing the game. collecting resources is extremely repetitive and slow, so is crafting, so is befriending people, and fighting, and pretty much every aspect of the game. everything is painfully longwinded and drawn out, taking a ridiculously long time for little payoff.
[*][b]length.[/b]
i'm never one to complain about how long a game is, the more there is to do the happier i am. this game is the one exception to that. all the story points feel so disjointed. it could end at so many points, but it has to add a new twist or an entirely new and unrelated story every time, which adds an extra 30 hours to the game each time. why has the story gone from developing this town, to catching a bandit, to [spoilers]rescuing a rat princess, to fighting in a war[/spoilers]. it strays so so far from the starting point that it's hard to stay interested, and that brings me to my next point.
[*][b]story.[/b]
it starts off so good, but what on earth happened. at some point you need to stop and question if what you're doing makes sense, and this game just doesn't. the game throws plot twist after plot twist at you, without putting much thought into any of them. none of them make sense, none of them are good ideas, it just feels like it's elongating this already immensely long game for no actual benefit.
[*][b]quality.[/b]
the game is very janky, which i personally think is fine for the most part, but it's worth mentioning. combat has you zipping around erratically, you can walk up almost vertical walls, mounts controls awfully, camera movement during dialogue is very strange, every cutscene is broken if there's a sandstorm going on, sandstorms don't actually do anything, there are almost no quality of life features, lots of invisible walls, there's not much attention to detail, and many features of the game feel very barebones. there's a lot more i could mention but this is already too long. the game just feels very much like they set their ambitions higher than they're able to reach. the fact i've got myself softlocked twice, and just downloaded a week 2 update which fixes 90+ bugs says a lot about the game. it just isn't well made.
[*][b]multiplayer[/b]
when this game was announced, it was planned to have multiplayer. not long before the release of the game, they decided to change that, after already receiving backing and early access purchases from people who were promised the game would have multiplayer. the game now has the most barebones and pointless multiplayer you can ask for, with no story or any of what makes the game fun.
[/list]

to summarise, this game has so much potential. it's a lovely idea, with some elements like character development and world building done remarkably well. however, the poor quality of the game, slow detioration of the story, and incredibly monotonous gameplay results in a very mediocre overall experience.

review:
[h2]ahoy![/h2]

this be ye local piratical reviewer comin' to tell ye if my time at sandrock be worth your precious doubloons or whether she be sent down to the briny depths!

i want to tell ye first, i've played the predecessor my time at portia to completin' and will be makin' some comparisons between 'em, i'll also be splittin' me thoughts into ayes 'n nays for easy readin'

[h3]ayes[/h3]

[b]a real sense o' progression[/b]
my time at sandrock (mtas) nails that sense of progression that my time at portia (mtap) pioneered. as ye be making ye adventures, ye'll be changing sandrock, from buildin' cranes te' fixing the hydrogel, expanding the yakmel network to more serious ventures like plantin' forests in the desert and building the road to portia. 

for each quest chain ye complete, you'll get reminders just how far ye've came. making ye feel apart of the world, and ultimately it's my most favourite draw to mtas.

[b]craftin'[/b]
goin' hand in hand with makin' ye changes in sandrock, the crafting is an improvement upon mtap. ye have a bounty o' machines to be gettin' ye buildin. most days ye'll be havin' machines runnin' all day pumpin out manner o things for ye designs. ingots, screws, slabs, everything to be gettin' everythin' built. occasionally, you'll feel overwhelmed but honestly, i felt that it feed it the hectic job that is bein' a builder in mtas. ye'll eventually condense this into ye crown jewel near the end, the almighty factory.

[b]exploration[/b]
the world of sandrock is huge and thar be plenty to see and dive. you'll be prowlin' through dangerous ruins, fighting robots and mobs for parts ye need for your builds and ye'll be spendin' a fair chunk o' ye time in the abandoned ruins, bringin' up various ores and relics to both smelt and reassemble. i've got no complaints.

[b]the characters[/b]
in this pirates honest opinions, the characters in mtas shine far brighter then those in portia. every character has a small chain that details there daily lives and a insight to their personality. it added that depth to life and some reason to care about the characters compared to portia, the massively expanded amount of quests featured in mtas, really helped in this situation.

[h3]nays[/h3]

[b]combat[/b]
thar has been a' few changes to combat, however, it still be simplistic. you'll be finding yourself usin' the same strategies ye found in portia. ye'll be dodging the choreographed events, going in to break' em and then just devastating 'em. it's the same ole' song and dance. it be worse with guns, ye'll whip your pistol o' rifle and just stun lock and break your enemy in place, making short work out most o' everything. disappointin' really.

[b]performance[/b]
this be nay gay breakin' but ye'll certainly notice it in ye adventurin'. mtas doesn't play aswell as portia, ye have pop in galore, especially o' anything ye've added to the world via the quests. the game chugs in the town itself and has random slow downs in various places. it can detract from ye' experience.

the small positive is for me, is that the game has mostly been light on bugs and pathea has been on the ball since release. 

[b]dlc practices[/b]
i hated to be addin' this one but ¬£4.49 for costumes for 4 characters and putting the favourites separate in individual packs is a practice that belongs in davey jones locker. either bundle them together for a tenner or reduce the price of the individuals. currently it looks a cash grab and add as a tarnish to this shining treasure.

[h3]conclusion n' scoring[/h3]
mtas is a large game and it's hard to condense everything inte' a few paragraphs. it's a massive improvement on mtap. if ye loved that game, ye'll be right at home here. a no brainer for ye doubloons.

if ye the kind of sailor that loves a solid sense o' progression with an in-depth crafting system, memorable characters and a massive chain of quests to go on and doesn't mind some minor annoyances and lacklustre combat system. ye'll definitely find some good sailing 'ere.

i give mtas a solid 8.5/10 gold doubloons. a massive improvement over portia if not marred by spotty performance and cheap dlc tactics.

review:
one of my favorite games of all time. has the most complex social aspects i've seen in a game and what we usually all wanted for years with life sim games. other devs should take notes, honestly. 

the best part about this game: there is always plenty things to do, and they are all fun and useful, a lot of life sim games might have you build useless things. almost everything you build gets used in events, main story content, bridges to unlock new areas, oh, and there is always new places being unlocked as you progress, immersive atmosphere, new characters being introduced, and i mean years in-game. 408 hrs (continued from early access save) and i am still unlocking new characters, areas, story content.

all the characters are well voice and well written. and by well written---really, well written. i don't think i can play a harvest moon or story of seasons game after this tbh. it's spoiled me. the characters are fleshed out wonderfully, with their own thought out pasts, stories, you can talk about them in convo during play dates, or romantic ones. some characters have reverse confessions and characters have romance and friendship quests as well as multiple in story quests where other characters will talk and interact with you and eachother. i guarantee you will feel some emotion for every single one of these characters. characters i didn't like or care about before i got to know i grew to like later, their flaws and their traits both, and their stories. 

this is one of the most immersive games i've experienced. it makes you feel apart of the community, and the seratonin boosts you get just from speaking to villagers, getting gifts outside your house on your birthday or wedding day, having your partner ask if you'd like to spend the day together after marriage and take you on little dates when most games are like 'they are married, have kids' and it's either the end, or they are blank nobodies now that have no more content whatsoever! this game doesn't do that. 

if sandrock gets more content dlc or in the next my time game, if they decide to have a kid system, i'd rather no kids unless there is real content for them, this is what the people want pathea, even if you charge $ for it:

-family outings/content and story events with your child/partner, and with the townsfolk
-the child going to school/interacting with other children
-old enough to speak properly/help out around the work shop or be interested in another profession/maybe story content for the kid following qi or owen around if they wanted to work as a scientist apprentice/at the blue moon as a chef or waiter or something.  ((not neccessary, just would be super cute. i would just rather not have kids in a game, like how stardew did unless they have content, sandrock still beat the others for sure though.)) and maybe a better child system to know when your child needs something/bring them with you on a baby backpack or hire a babysitter if you can't be home.

i'm definitely doing another playthrough. it's easy to miss dialogue and content because there is so much((this is a good thing.)) we got so lucky with my time at sandrock and i feel like i would 100% die for any of the sandrockers fr. the story gets better and better. sometimes it's silly, sometimes it's serious, sometimes it's just fun. 

characters you befriend will someetimes show up outside your house because they miss you and want to hang out, and sometimes you will see a lot of ! events to unlock, where you can say to much is going on right now and get to it later.

you might walk into someones home and they are eating dinner together, arvios sister is visiting him, or the preacher is teaching jasmine how to speak politely if she didn't like an authors book. little details that bring life

oh, and don't get me started on the holidays. only game i cared about holidays. you have mini games on almost every one, from collecting ingredients on a yakmel and can bump into other people, grilling up food for the towns folk, a dance competition, and so much more.

on dates with friends and romantically, you can set off fireworks in a fun pattern of your choosing, draw in the sand, play whack a mole or games at the arcade, sit and talk on a bench or go out to eat and order them food. you can befriend folks easily without gift spamming. talking to them, being yourself and taking commissions/work on the request or commission board they asked for is helpful. some characters might need to unlock events to get there story or even be able to give gifts to them if they are more to themselves.

the personalities are well thought out. characters with pasts, multiple hobbies likes and dislikes, where most games the 'fisherman' is just a fisherman and nothing more, his entire personality. you will hear them talk about their family, their other interests, and things they like. the characters entire personality isnt just a trope or based around 1 thing. this is the best character development as well for some characters i've seen in a long time. i highly reccomend buying this. it will be a blast constantly.

usually life sims have moments when your bored. well 400 hrs in and still constant content. i'm just saying....i hope this becomes the new standard for life sims xd

review:
i don't leave reviews often so let me explain why i am this time first then i'll talk about sandrock.  back in 2014 i bought pathea's (first?  think so?) game called planet explorers.  i loved it at first but it had such a long development then in 2016 they "full released" the game, all while i still encountered game breaking bugs in the first 10min of gameplay that i had when i first started the game in '14.  coming off of also getting burned on several other steam greenlight games (yall remember that s**t?!), i swore that i would never, ever, buy another pathea game again..... then in 2018 i saw this cute game pop up in my feed called my time at portia, i was immediately in love with the art style and premise of the game and bought immediately, somehow missing the pathea logos and name the entire time.  by the time i realized that they were made by the same devs i had like some 100+hrs in portia and exhausted all the content even available at the time.  i did become a bit doomer and just awaited it to just disappear into history as another abandoned game.... well i have 300+ hours in portia now and it ranks as one of my favorite games of all time.  so firstly, i want to thank pathea games for doing a complete flip in my book and coming out with absolute bangers that have lost me many hours in workshop (my real one not the one in game, that workshop gets overused!)

now, lets talk about sandrock specifically (no story spoilers dont worry).  i had no idea it was even coming until it was too late to even back it on kickstarted and i hated myself for it!  i mean look at sandrock!  it has everything i love portia and then just completely redid it or made it even better.  the art style is such a nice thing to look at, the animations feel so much more complete and the gameplay feels nice and balanced and gives you full freedom to play how you will with very little in the way of forcing progress except when you really want to.  don't wanna go ultra super heavy into making your workshop mega and just wanna socialize?  you got it!  or you can do what i do and take #1 builder before the first month is even over (suck it yan!). the characters are all so lovable or just absolutely memorable to me, pen is such a over the top dude, yan while being your main 'rival' doesn't like actively take commissions from you like higgins did (no more sprinting off to the guild to grab the good commissions before he does), and miguel as much as i don't like him like him i at least have an understanding of him and even at times sympathize with his views.  i was put off at first by how you get more resources from recyclers rather than just straight gather (which there is still plenty of!) but in time i grew to really enjoy that i could have all them crunching for copper while i go get iron.  everything about it feels so well thought and improved from portia while not feeling like they just ctrl+c ctrl+v.  while it does get tedious at first managing both water and fuel for machines it became second nature when i run over to machine to start new production to just auto fill with dregs and i rarely had an issue anymore of machine out of water/fuel(by the way never ever use your wood for fuel just go slap some powerstones or get some dregs, thank me later).  the greatest improvement imo is combat which feels leagues ahead of the combat i remember from portia and i actually like dungeon diving now (before it was more ugh ok i guess ill go...).  socializing also feels alot easier in this game, admittedly i tend to always put socializing on the back burner but in my now post release game everyone loves me.  the one thing i really complained about was it felt like i had not enough time to do everything i wanted because i had to run here or there to get things done but that got solved when i found the time slider, won't really help you crunch resources faster since those are timed to in game time, but it's easier to run home and start something to turn in a com without running out of time due to me spending time walking, i found that a .67 time setting to be a nice sweet spot for getting places without dragging a day too long.  

and on the story itself, again, no spoilers, but it's good, really good imo.  it kept me hooked and interested the whole way, and also laughing because this game doesn't try to make everything so serious even in the more serious parts of the game (there's always a punch line xd). i got so excited in the last major update before release that i couldn't help myself but again play all through the twist and turns of what i think is the climax of the game (haven't full played on release yet so idk if theres even more after that!) and even after completing it i didn't feel like i was done or satisfied, there was still more work to do, still more commissions to get and more to build and to get sandrock back to its former glory (and even better!).  before release, i had just shy of 300hrs in sandrock and in the past 2 weeks, even with my bloated work schedule these days ive blown 80hrs in my new playthough and i can definately see myself blowing another 300 on this game before i get 'tired' of it. 

the tldr of it is, yes, buy this game.  you'll love it, play how you want to play, don't get the biggest baddest workshop if you dont want to, dont socialize alot if you dont want to.  or do!  sit back, relax, take a load off your mind and just create and have fun or go full try hard and show that yan dude whose the real newbie.  and pathea, from the just in my opinion let down of planet explorers, you have my eternal gratitude for portia and sandrock and you have won me fully back and just eager for the day the next my time at x game comes out (highwind!? altara? i mean coooommmmee ooooonnnn!!!)

last thought, nemo is best doggo because is quite literally a copy of my best doggo at home.  anyone who says other pet is best pet is lying and you should ignore them.

review:
[h1]i liked it.[/h1]
i liked portia, and i liked this game. just finished it! lots to do, the story is much more significant than i expected. thumbs up.

...with caveats. i had hoped that this time around we'd be able to avoid some of the pitfalls that portia had, and there were exotic new pitfalls to enjoy as well.

[h2]spoilers ahead, sorry. skip to conclusion for non-spoilery assessment[/h2]

[h3]the good[/h3]
[list]
[*]unsuur
[*]lots of story content, more than portia
[*]you get to feel epic as the townies come to respect you
[*]the civil corps of sandrock acknowledges you as an honorary member instead of pretending for the entire game that they are stronger than you in spite of your combat prowess like the civil corps of portia did
[*]didn't rely pretty much at all on any of the old workshop machines from the old game, and new models where there was overlap
[*]had a much more effective environmental message, where portia kind of deliberately put you at odds with the environmentalists in the game while trying to talk about the importance of environmentalism
[*]some (some) of the voice acting was pretty good
[*]i liked the weapon variety and specialization you could do through knowledge points
[*]did a decent job of making it so you could stop hunting for older, low-level ore and minerals while still making you track down new ores and occasional rarities like engines and stuff.
[*]datable men in this game are way hotter than in portia. so are the women, but the glow-up award goes to the guys. much better fleshed out personalities across the board too.
[*]i really liked hanging out and dating being instant instead of scheduled for a specific time the next day.
[/list]

[h3]the bad[/h3]
[list]
[*]arvio
[*]nearly every model that's not a permanent feature of the landscape takes a long time to load in
[*]quite a bit of the voice acting and sound design is somewhere between questionable and bad
[*]pacing is often weird. see section below.
[*]dating and hanging out still isn't fun
[*]there is no contest whatsoever in the builder rankings. i beat yan in year one without trouble, and in year two mi-an didn't come close. i could have done just one commission a day and i still would have been miles ahead. i expected mi-an to surge ahead to at least claim some yan-level numbers once yan wasn't taking credit for all her work, but she just wasn't remotely a threat.
[*]there was not nearly enough variety in the commissions. never-ending metal ingots, metal plates, stone slabs, petrified wood planks and sticks, and canvas were my reward for climbing to five stars. why aren't people commissioning more, you know... built stuff?
[*]what the hell happened to the factory? in portia it had an awesome animated interior and dedicated upgrade options. in sandrock it's an ugly living room with all your machines crammed into it as cramped as you can manage. in portia it worked with the automated half of your assembly station, but in sandrock you wish you could just delete your assembly station entirely because you'll never use it again.
[*]i never once used a powerstone of either grade. i found it impossible to run out of dregs.
[*]i love merle, but i wanted a goat with rambo's horns.
[*]there's a whole upgrade in the abandoned ruins goggles to let you see the outline of the items you scan. only problem is every scannable item is smaller than the diamond indicator so you'll never actually see the outline of anything. portia had no such issue.
[*]sandrock fails in multiple instances to teach you about functions of the game. i never once learned to use a camera, so i had a whopping zero photos at the end of the game. i was made aware of the existence of parties thanks to the resources i had to make them go over well, but i only learned from the end credits that i was supposed to purchase and set up a banquet table to unlock this feature. i discovered that many of the datable npcs have outfit options in the social menu. i never found out how to make those happen. the fashion show seemed like the time for that to unlock, but the outfits were never made purchaseable, despite barber guy's enthusiasm about selling them in his dialogue. i thought maybe it was dlc, but it turns out it's not, so how was that meant to unlock? maybe after you marry them? nope. still no idea.
[*]i gave grace a custom pet name to call me when we got married. she just called me sugar instead.
[*]i am genuinely unsure if there are enough small items to donate to the museum to successfully fill the small item slots available
[*]the house builder interface is janky as hell. sometimes you just have to quit and go back in to get anything done as various items refuse to bring up their interaction options, become unmovable, become unresizable, or just plain disappear because of an errant click. was it a workshop machine? then don't bother checking your inventory or the "workshop machine" menu on the builder interface, because it's now in your mailbox. so better get your ass back home to get that item and then head back to the house builder thing to try and remember what you were doing.
[/list]

pacing issues
[list]
[*]i earned a greenhouse before i was ever able to develop a single tile of biocrust naturally, despite nonstop gardening starting the moment gardening was available. even without the greenhouse, the main story gifted me enough biocrust to make generating it manually a pointless feature.
[*]i was excited to get my max-level spear, but i earned the laser sword before i could make one and it was the indisputable optimal choice, rendering my knowledge points in spears worthless
[*]in portia the final build, a plane, blindsides you with a sudden need for truckloads of crystals you never thought to harvest before and makes you take in-game weeks just waiting for them to spawn so you can finish the quest. sandrock's elegant answer to this problem is to make the final build embarrassingly easy to complete. you'll probably have it finished in an afternoon with materials you had laying around. please, by all means, send me on a couple days of fetching to get the parts i need for this once-in-a-game build. they're never going to ask for another one, so make them unique items that i need to fight some boss monsters to obtain or something. i don't know, but "a single expedition's worth of nanomaterial scrap and poplar wood and (checks notes) an item made a tiny amount of copper and bronze" can't possibly be the best answer.
[*]in both portia and sandrock, the factory is a double-edged sword. it feels awesome to unlock godmode in your workshop, but you'll never have to think meaningfully about any commissions or build quests again. that's the day you go from bustling builder to rare material scavenger, and there's no going back, really. it was also too cheap and easy to have a factory in this game. couple grand, you're good to go. at least in portia you had to gather a mess of expensive materials and pony up the cash.
[*]you'll have the max-level workshop equipment by about the halfway point of the game. upgrading feels nice, so it's sad when this goes away so soon.
[/list]

[h3]conclusion[/h3]
this is a fundamentally fun game that, like its predecessor, is deeply flawed. it has heart, but it feels unfinished in a way i know they're not going to fix. i had hoped portia would serve as a learning experience that would lead to sandrock being far more optimized out the gate. instead, it's genuinely unclear if they learned much of anything from portia's issues.

would i buy a new entry in this series in the future? well... probably. because they did at least prove they have some fun new ideas that do iterate successfully on the "my time at" formula. but at this point pathea is cementing itself in my head as a studio with a lot of muscle in the ideas department, but anemic in the polish department. the public is growing weary of studios that can't release a finished game.

review:
mtas is, from the get-go, very similar to its predecessor my time at portia and for the most part that holds true as this was supposed to be an expansion before turning into a separate project.

does it separate itself enough to warrant a separate purchase? i believe so, although i believe the price increased since early access when i purchased it.

initially i was put off by the chosen setting as having a farming game be set in a desolate desert setting seemed like a tall order but the developers managed to introduce new mechanics to account for this without removing one of the core parts of the original game. i will not go into detail as some of these mechanics are also tied to the story which is appreciated as well. they may seem a bit tedious at the beginning but eventually as with the previous games most of the energy/water requirements become trivial from simply farming out other resources which i find to be nice as the game is already pretty grindy as its predecessor was in some aspects. a quick tip: do try to get a pet asap as they help a ton.
how grindy the game feels however depends on what you as the player would like to do and how stressed you feel about worker of the month/year nominations. if you want to keep ahead you will be farming 3-4 commissions daily as well as blowing all your stamina in abandoned ruins which can become a bit of a repetitive chore (for me this feeling started somewhere around winter 1st year). in order to avoid this i would recommend engaging with other parts of the game as well (hangouts/romance/building the house/farm) and not feeling like you need to squeeze out every ounce of stamina out of every day otherwise you will burn out quickly.

in terms of the story i still have not reached the complete conclusion but i believe nobody expected this game to bring out a game of the year contender in this regard.
if there is one thing however i would say that the pacing feels off for me. lot of the progression is gated by arbitrary amounts of days that have to pass in order for you to even receive an email that will tell you (at the beginning of a given day) that the story will continue 2 days from now. after those 2 days pass you usually go to a fireside meeting where they will say something usually followed by another day or 2 of waiting which became a real point of frustration as i already blew through all the mining/building content and needed story to progress to access the 3rd abandoned ruins which never seem to come. at this point i am in year 2 spring and i have been done with all that 2nd abandoned ruins offer in year 1 day 26 autumn which means i spent most of winter just running around hoping a side-quest would appear or the story would hurry up and come but it never did as from what i read i am still a few mysterious letters off from actually getting to the ruins. feels like i am being drip fed story at this point which would be fine if i was not done with everything i can do in a given day at about 3pm with plenty of time to spare.

hangouts/romance are pretty similar to what they were in portia but i appreciate the variety of characters that are available although i do miss papa bear. i thought sandy was going to be a nice replacement for papa bear for me but the sound that camel makes evoke some primordial feelings of horror in me so i avoid her usually.
one thing that i find odd is how easy it is to become a bff with heidi specifically since many of the commissions are from her so even if i do not really care about her she is my best friend stat-wise since avoiding her commissions would be hamstringing my progress too much. of course with addition of a bounty board this levels out a bit as those requests (at least in my experience) came from a variety of characters usually not requesting standard commissions like elsie for example who in my play-through appeared on standard commission board maybe twice with a incredibly simple request that yields almost no rewards.

all in all it might seem like i am airing my grievances with the game which is true but i still really like it for what it is. it may not be perfect owing to the points above or the bugs which still plague it but i do believe it is a great experience for people who liked the first game and builds upon it well. the grind feels satisfying when done in moderation and there are a lot of options for customizing your yard and house. romance options are plenty and compared to the first game there seem to be more post-marriage content.
i do hope future brings more bugfixes and even content if we should be so lucky.

p.s.
if a sequel ever comes i do hope for a different environment though as portia was also 1/3 if not 1/2 desert which i understand is a rather major plot point in the overall story but i am kind of over sand now, thanks.

review:
this is one of the best life simulator games i have ever played, hands down! it does have a few minor problems but they're barely notable and the pros here far outweigh any cons.

what i think...

+ pros +
++++++++
+ beautiful visuals and characters
+ astounding game mechanics
+ tons and i do mean tons to do for hours on end
+ awesome crafting system
+ awesome building/upgrade system
+ easy to understand and play
+ challenging enemies
+ lots of quests and side missions
+ mail system that actually makes sense and lets you respond
+ town news that makes sense, you can subscribe to get updates on things happening in town
+ finally, a town that feels and looks legit, lots of stores, an arcade, and more
+ lots of mini games and events
+ lots of glorious cutscenes
+ feels very realistic in a lot of ways
+ gameplay draws you in a lot
+ lots of collectibles
+ lots of areas
+ singleplayer and multiplayer
+ lots of replay value


- cons -
----------
- multiplayer starts of with no house and a lot of missing buildings, this makes absolutely no sense
- controls in multiplayer are by default different than singleplayer, this too makes absolutely no sense
- player water tower to refill with water should have a visual meter to indicate water in it since it's extremely annoying just to have to open it up to check ever time and that makes it difficult to know if you're running low or not while busy with other town commisions and such. a simple visual meter on the side of the tank would make life so much better.
- a lot of the pop-ups such as hints/tips from quests and wandering around show up during cutscenes and can easily be missed as they don't stay there long so you might miss something important and thats very frustating


= verdict =
==========
= my time at sandrock takes everything about the first game and makes it even better plus a little more! there is literally so much detail and realism packed into this wonderful stylized game to keep you busy with the game for hours on end and when you think it stops no it doesn't you can take things on again pretty much through continued multiplayer! its a wonderful game with so many great gameplay machanics and you'll never want to put it down! i highly recommend it! i really hope to see this game come to android as well like the first one did! i would buy it on mobile in a heartbeat! thanks devs for making this amazing game!

review: was an early supporter of this game because i loved my time at portia. sandrock is just as amazing as portia, i feel like portia and sandrock are the only games of its kind. panthea never fails, this one, just like portia was full of twist, full of love-able and hate-able characters. the bachelors are top tier, same with some of the bachelorettes. a lot is improved from portia, i feel like there's way more sentiments for the characters and i actually think this game felt longer then portia. it was really fun trying to stop the desertification, and its always fun to be able to fight against duvos, like the first game. if another game comes along in this series (pc/console game, i know there's a mobile, which ill probably play too). i will 100% buy, i know they teased as an april fools my time at duvos, which, since that's a city under a dictatorship and is the problem for most of the free cities, my god, would be amazing. i know they have a lot of towns they can work with, through both games and hopefully there's more to the story, more games in the future, because i am invested.

review:
my time at optimizing is a cutesy, cozy, post apocalyptic life sim.

enjoy characters that make you think you might be a bully on the inside and dialouge written by 2 guys that went to the same comedy course together. voice acted characters that will make you feel like the only real person in a universe full of robots are here too to spruce up your free time and welcome you to your shack far outside of city bounds because no way in hell are they sharing space with your filthy ass.

there are many things to do! spend your time recycling wood, recycling stone, recycling metal and even recycling rubber. ask other inhabitants of sandrock to join you in any of the over 1 activities on offer. become a neet strategist as you attempt to figure out how half the seasonal event work. give up and recycle wood again! exciting!!!

now if you'll excuse me i have to pay out of pocket for a new water tower less we all die of dehydration within the next week and the church zealots that rule this town do not hand out credit even for life threatening disasters that affect all of us. don't you dare ever ask for anything for any goverment contracts.

enjoy. 8/10 (i really do like it. i'm dating the divorced single mom it makes up for everything.)

review:
my time at portia was already a great game with a lot of interesting and fun ideas, but this new game, just got most of the (many) clunky bits from the original title, applied a shiny new coat of beautiful paint over them, fixed most of the issues, added a ton of qol improvements and focused on being a fleshed fun experience with hours upon hours of content. and even then, they also managed to slap multiplayer and coop mode, too!

for the price, this is truly a gem that will keep you entertained for hundreds of hours. this is now the equivalent of stardew valley on 3d, with its own ideas and style.

just a fun, campy and wholesome experience that delivers what it promises.

if you liked portia, or any other similar game, you will surely enjoy your time in sandrock!

more games like this, please!

review:
[i]my time at portia[/i] was a real surprise for me when i first played it. i'm pretty sure i got it in a bundle. it looked like someone had repurposed the assets of a korean mmo from 2010. but it turned out to be an unexpectedly feature rich game with an interesting post-apocalyptic worldbuilding, gameplay with genuinely novel ideas in combining the day-to-day work cycle and socializing of [i]harvest moon[/i] with softer factory game mechanics and combat, and just a good amount of content that was fun despite the jank.

[i]my time at sandrock[/i] takes all the good ideas of its predecessor which felt accidentally good at many times, and elevates them so you can make no mistake that pathea are actually a really talented and hardworking company that knows what they're doing. is it free of jank? no, not really. but it's so chockful of good things that even the jank becomes charming. it has a great, interesting story full of characters with vibrant personalities and not the paper-thin cutouts you get in [i]stardew valley[/i]. the world of the setting is so fully realized despite the series' cartoony nature and you feel excited to explore and learn about it. it is genuinely laugh out loud funny at many points, and genuinely emotional at others. i have to give it up for the vas who don't seem like professionals but are still giving their best. the building gameplay while its core loop is the same, sees a lot of qol improvements. the combat is more dynamic and offers a bit of challenge though it's still on the casual side. there's so many small charming details too, like when you go on dates in-game, they put in an animation where your significant other holds your hand. they didn't have to do that. it has no mechanical value. it's just cute and it makes you feel good.

stuff like that is why i think most of all, what the game nails is that it makes it good to be in sandrock, and to see sandrock grow. everyone who plays games for long enough understands the feeling where a place in a game becomes like a real place we have visited and been in, and we feel a sort of nostalgia seeing it. i think sandrock will feel that way to many people playing the game, it's such a wonderfully crafted setting, and it really fulfills the promise of the genre of "life sim" where you can take a break from reality and live somewhere else for a little while. i'm not even done with the main story. i restarted with 1.0 to experience it as intended since in beta lots of the quests squished together in buggy ways as they were implemented, but i feel glad to have done that. this is gonna be a game i will have good memories of and consider a favorite years from now.

p.s. just to be clear, i'm only really reviewing the single-player experience. i have not tried and am not that fussed about multiplayer.

review:
i am recommending this game because a friend of mine recommends it. 

but i have one big thing to say that may affect if you should buy this game or not.

if you want to play multiplayer, you are stuck to a singular character per server. you cannot have multiple characters on a server and thus if you p[ay with a friend, but want to play fresh with another friend- you either delete your current character and make a new one, or change to a different server and make one there. 

that is my only complaint, nor have i played the game enough to give any further context on the game.

review:
fantastic game, i immensely enjoyed my experience playing it. while not perfect, it massively improves on many aspects from its predecessor, my time at portia (mtap), while successfully experimenting with new ideas. most of my gripes with the game are largely small, inconsequential things, though there are a couple that really stood out as being almost impressively bad for such a great game. overall i loved it and i'm crushed that my play-through has ended. 8.5/10

[h3] pros [/h3]
 - huge boost in qol from mtap; inventory management is a dream, voiced dialogue is consistent instead of feeling random, you have more freedom to explore, and so on 
 - performance; i have a gtx 1070 and an i7700k so my rig is definitely aging...however i was easily able to keep my fps at 70+. the only dips were when most/all of the cast was on screen at once and was moving around (some firesides, but oddly not an issue during any of the festivals)
 - content; i just finished all the quests and my save file reads at 144 hours. there is a shockingly gargantuan amount of content to play through. while there are always "fetch this" quests, very few felt like their main purpose was to add filler *coughacvalhallacough* and the main quests carried a strong identity (sandrock is a dying town and constantly goes from crisis to crisis)
 - cast/writing; i felt most of the vas did a great job and overall the writing did a great job in both conveying humor and seriousness. every quest you take with justice + unsuur is full of golden dialogue, burgess is wonderfully self-aware, and so on.
 - music; a major step-up from mtap. i mean, the musical score for mtap wasn't bad per se...well the combat music and ruins exploration music were both pretty...okay everything but the sparring music was pretty mediocre (the sparring music slapped). mtas has a much, *much* better musical score in essentially every aspect.
 - impact; you as the protagonist have a large and meaningful impact in the game. sandrock goes through a food crisis, water crisis, vegetation crisis, and you can visually see the effects they have on the town, both before and after. it made me feel, in my opinion at least, like what i was doing was...purposeful, helpful. 
 - combat; they really stepped up the combat from mtap and it is a much smoother and more enjoyable experience. there are distinct weapon types: [strike] dual blades [/strike] daggers, greatsword, [strike] insect-less glaive [/strike] spear and [strike] sns [/strike] sword + shield, along with some guns, throwables, and a couple unique weapons. 
 - quality; less of a "pro" and more of "not a con", any game where items/gear posses quality tiers is fraught with danger. sandrock does a great job with quality (aside from the names, i mean ordinary -> oustanding -> perfect -> rare doesn't make sense to me). you can refine many items/weapons/gear to raise their level at the expense of a couple gems/minerals and it never feels like a brutal grind to do so....except for any item that wants agate to level up, agate sucks to get. literally everything else though is totally fine.
 - creativity; as mentioned sandrock is built on a pitifully small oasis. it used to be lush but has been almost entirely claimed by desertification. mechanically, the game requires you to use water to "cool" your machines (water being one of the very few parts of the game that remained an actual obstacle throughout the play through). you are not allowed to cut down any trees within the boundaries of sandrock proper (early game finding wood is a unique challenge). these, along with taking over a dozen kinds of scrap into the new recycling machines, do a fantastic job of mixing up game play and how new tiers of materials get introduced.

[h3] neutral [/h3] 
 - skill tree; your experience gets both added to a total, overall level (health/stamina) and divided into either social, gathering, workshop or combat based on where the xp was earned. this is a mixed bag for me because the perks are very obviously either "must-haves" (+1 break damage, +1 daily commission) or "super terrible" (any of the *many* perks that give you +10% xp/chance for/etc). the extra xp is bad because....

[h3] cons: [/h3] (review too long, only showing the two that plagued me)
 - difficulty; the game is easy. no, that's not fair. it is stunningly, disappointingly, shockingly easy. i'm not asking this to be dark souls; if i wanted that i'd...go play dark souls. what i mean is that i was over-leveled (>= 8 levels above) for 90% of the game,  and massively over-leveled (>= 14) for about 40% of it. the greater the level difference, the less damage is taken/received a-la borderlands style. immunity frames when dodging are [i] incredibly [/i] generous; you have i-frames for the entire animation and a little extra, meaning you can just chain rolls for invulnerability and you can lazily roll through the few environmental obstacles thrown at you. however, as you are far above the recommended level, you won't even be dodging because you barely get hurt. the bosses are actually well designed, far better than mtap...but again, you don't need to engage in any of their mechanics you are a much higher level than they. also there are 0 attacks that cannot be avoided by simply....running in a different direction. earned experience points are also far too generous. sparring pen and the dive buzzard near the railroad tracks were the only two fights that i felt challenged; every other combat experience was a cake-walk. pathea could slash all earned xp by 25% and *maybe* you'd fall into the recommended range, but only if you never explored, did side quests or commissions. this is why 40% of the skill tree feels pointless. every perk doesn't need to be in perfect balance...but i'm already stomping everything i do not need a 10% chance to get double experience for kicking trees. gear cannot be used it you are below it's specified level but, once more, that had 0 effect on my gameplay outside of the first couple in-game weeks. sandstorms are supposed to be deadly, you are told to either stay inside or don protective gear. spoiler, it doesn't matter. wear whatever you want. the game makes some light attempts into platforming (which were done well) with the exception of the massive arrows that always tell you where to go. i could go on; suffice it to say i loved so much of the game but i never really felt "challenged" at virtually any point.
 - path finding. i mean wow, i was blown away by how unbelievably abysmal the path finding is. i've watched sandrock residents get stuck walking into building corners, get stuck walking into plants, decorations, each other, things that are invisible to me yet inexplicably manifest a collision box, animals, fences...if it exists in game, they've gotten stuck on it. repeatedly. in the first 3 minutes of the game you are offered a tour by the ten-year-old jasmine who after saying, "follow me" immediately turns around and gets stuck on a rock. the "solution" was to cause a character to fade out and reappear after they fail to move in their desired direction for a couple seconds. they only sometimes do that. sometimes they just give up and stand there until something breaks their error loop (if you host a party expect to talk to everybody constantly so they dont freeze in place). sometimes the pathing routes of everybody (enemies included) get shifted. now the bumble ants that are on the hill 200 feet to the east of your workshop eternally try to path into your fence. if a sandrocker has been catastrophically shifted from their normal route you may watch as they teleport back and forth between two spots (looking at your pen, rocky and krystal). your children are a complete enigma and refuse to abide by any pathfinding laws. good luck trying to change that diaper before you lose relationship with them and your spouse because they crawled outside the clearly-defined boundaries of your home.

review:
[h2] multiplayer feedback for my time at sandrock [/h2]

firstly, we want to express our appreciation for the unique multiplayer experience you've introduced in my time at sandrock. after investing over 50 hours+ into the game, my wife and i compiled our thoughts and feedback, focusing primarily on the multiplayer aspect. it's important to note that our feedback pertains exclusively to multiplayer, as we have yet to explore the single-player mode.

[b] let's delve into the areas that could use improvement: [/b]

[h3] 1. lack of freedom in a server-based world [/h3]
the introduction of a server-based world is both a blessing and a curse. while the ability to play even when the host is inactive is commendable, it restricts player freedom. in contrast to the multiplayer mechanics of [b]stardew valley[/b], where an account-based server offers players the freedom to modify the game using mods, console commands, and more, [b]my time at sandrock[/b] a sandbox multiplayer game focus falls short in this regard.
[list]
[*] comparison with stardew valley multiplayer

stardew valley allows mods and extensive customization, adding costumes to npcs, changing npc portraits, incorporating extra heart events, enhancing ui, introducing new characters, implementing console commands, even freezing time and more. the only limitation is the necessity for the host to be active, a trade-off that hasn't posed a significant issue, since i can just turn on my pc (i'm the host) and let them do whatever they want in the farm, even if my character faints due to lack of sleep, there are no adverse consequences or losses incurred because of the mods.

[*] impact on gameplay experience

the current server-based setup in [b]my time at sandrock[/b] detracts from the immersive storytelling experience. if one player is offline, progressing through quests and other activities becomes challenging due to the accelerated passage of in-game time. this time constraint induces stress rather than fostering a relaxing gameplay environment. the server is very strict when modifying our own world.
[/list]

[h3] 2. time progression does not stop in multiplayer mode even if you are alone. [/h3]
[list]
[*] a notable drawback of the server-based approach is that in multiplayer worlds with only one active player, time relentlessly marches on regardless if you are in menu mode, inventory, etc. this poses a challenge for players who meticulously plan and min-max their activities, especially when friends are offline. try to implement a "private/account based" multiplayer world, allowing players to host their own servers, would offer a solution to this predicament and empower players to play the game on their terms. ( some might say, stop playing and wait for your friends to get online ). 
[i]that would counter the fact that the multiplayer server-based is [b]useless[/b] since we have to wait for everyone to be online, right?[/i]
[/list]

[h3] 3. achievements and milestones in multiplayer [/h3]

[list]
[*] adding achievements to multiplayer mode seems to be a missed opportunity. while the game already features milestones, incorporating a system to track personal achievements and synchronizing them with steam achievements would enhance the multiplayer experience. if some achievement is only accessible in singleplayer, then we would have another reason to play the singleplayer mode.

[*] yes, you can play multiplayer mode for 500+ hours, complete everything you need and you still have 0/60 achievements. 
not cool.
[/list]

[h3] 4. shared storage challenges and quest completion [/h3]

[list]
[*] the existing shared storage system, offering capacities of 80(?), 120, and 300 at levels 1, 2, and 3, respectively, introduces significant challenges, particularly during the [b]early and mid-game phases[/b]. this challenge is accentuated in multiplayer scenarios where multiple players contribute to the shared storage. once the shared storage reaches its capacity, we're compelled to resort to "personal storage," limiting access for other players.

[*] the inconvenience arises when different players hold distinct resources, gone offline then other players need those items for quests. they will have to farm again, since time does not stop. unlike the seamless, automatic quest item retrieval feature present in single-player mode, the multiplayer experience introduces additional complexities, requiring deliberate coordination among players to ensure efficient quest completion.
[/list]

[h3] final note [/h3]

since this review is heavily focused on the multiplayer mode, we regrettably find it necessary to vote "do not recommend" for players specifically seeking a satisfying multiplayer experience. we remain hopeful that future updates will address these concerns, and we are open to revising our review once improvements are implemented.

review:
if you liked my time at portia or even found it flawed with potential, sandrock improves on it in pretty much every way. if you like life sims/crafting games, you may like this. you get an unbelievable amount of content and customization and replayability for your money. it's not flawless, but i really like what's there a whole lot.

you do not need to have played my time at portia to play sandrock is stands alone.

plays well with either mouse and keyboard or controller (i used controller)

the community you live and work in will dynamically change over the course of the story, people will come and go from town, and everyone has something to say about major story beats.

review: this is the first game i ever tried early access for, because even though portia had its issues on switch, i sunk several hours into it happily. i can firmly say i don't regret it for a moment. today is official launch day and even though my campaign will not be wiped, i'm excited to start over and enjoy everything again. this game sits perfectly at my interests. it's got a nice combat system, socializing, farming too, you can take quests at your own pace for the most part, you have so much customization for your character, house, and much more. yes, there is the very occasional non-game breaking bug, but those are always addressed by the devs and it feels like they listen to the fan base. you can really feel the love of the community and developers in this game. i can't wait to sink my teeth into 1.0.  thank you for my time at sandrock! i hope to see even more my time's!

review: in my opinion, it's a step up from portia in every way. i was never able to fully get into portia due to the building aspect being tedious when having to hold every item (small gripe, i know, but big enough to always hinder my playthroughs. i always end up quitting shortly after the cart building mission). not in sandrock. you can craft anything on the assembly station with materials straight from your chests. the quality of life upgrades to sandrock are very significant. the story is compelling, along with the large cast of diverse characters. unsuur is my himbo boyfriend, and i wouldn't trade him for any rock in the world. if you liked portia even just a little (or liked portia in theory but not practice like me), definitely give sandrock a try, because it's a  step up in every direction, and a perfect example of the devs fixing what needed to be fixed, without getting rid of what made it a good game in the first place.

review:
[h1] basically mtap but better and more [/h1]
[h2] tl;dr [/h2]
basically, if you've played and enjoyed my time at portia, you'll enjoy this as it's more of the same but higher quality, there's more content, some of the kinks have been worked out and generally this is what i would classify as a good sequel.

if you haven't played mtap: this is essentially a "cozy" farm life sim game with all the genre staples (npc relationships, expanding operations, planning your day and your season in order to maximize ‚Ç¨$, home customization, yada yada bing bong), except replace "farm" with "mechanic".
you take on requests for materials and finished products which progress in complexity as you upgrade and expand your workshop with new machines, better equipment, et cetera.

the game offers some customization of your experience, including a slider that speeds up or slows down the passage of in-game time. if you're into this genre of games, you will like this game. it's well put together, i personally haven't encountered any breaking bugs, it performs well, it looks nice and there's a lot to do.
[hr][/hr]

[h2]in detail[/h2]
[h3]the good[/h3]
[b]graphical quality[/b]
the game is quite a step up from portia, and comparing it to other offerings within the genre that adopt 3d visuals, i think only harvestella has it beat, in terms of technical quality (shaders, lighting, texture work et cetera) and details such as tufts of grass bobbing in the wind, sand particles and dust clouds blowing over arid terrain, npcs and mobs reacting to things happening around them.

[b]performance[/b]
i'm playing this on deck. when i first tried this on deck when i bought it roughly a year ago, i was forced to put the settings to a low preset, and my deck struggled to maintain 30fps. in the current version, in the year of our lord 2023, i have every graphical setting maxed out and the game is running between 30 and 60 fps on average. easily hitting 60fps in interiors.
all in all, with how the game looks, i think the performance is pretty impressive.

[b]sheer volume of content[/b]
i'm roughly 20 hours in to a new save on this version, and it feels as though i have yet to finish the first chapter in the story - i'm still witnessing new character introductions, npcs treat me as the "new builder". at the same time, literally every day since starting the game (i'm roughly at the end of the first in-game month) i've started the day with a new unique situation unfolding that day, ranging between character plot and main story beats, sometimes unlocking new features, sometimes unlocking new areas, sometimes just offering up new insights in characters or the world.
there also appears to be quite a breath of content. i haven't dipped my to into every system yet - i honestly don't even know roughly how much of the systems on offer i've engaged with. however, on top of the workshop, it appears you also gain access to more traditional elements such as farming plots and animal keeping. then there's a whole slew of activities available on certain days of the week, usually small in scope but quite numerous, such as making weekly deliveries of clay to the pottery artisan or helping with cleaning up the communal water supply. these may be simple activities, but they do help build a sense of community and add authenticity to the setting.
there's a lot more, but i can't be arsed getting in to it. just know that the main meat of the game (running the workshop) has quite a bit of depth, and at the same time there's breadth of content in the periphery.

[b]writing[/b]
people who played mtap know this already - the writers at pathea seem to have quite a bit of fun adding character to, well, the characters. this games' script has a lot of moving parts: when certain events trigger is directly influenced by your actions as a player, so the order in which events happen can't be guaranteed. despite this, the tone of the script is quite consistent. even if when you jump from a serious scene where the titular town is under assault to one where a writer is receiving eloquently phrased harsh critiques from a kid ("i'm in your tawget demogwaphic" cracked me up) and you can see his heart break a little. this is all backed up by surprisingly good voice acting. the voice cast is varied, mostly fits the characters being depicted and the direction is excellent. this is a step up from portia.
i think they spent more time proofreading the game script as well, as even the little stuff like item and skill descriptions have been immaculate so far.

[b]game flow[/b]
this is hard to pin down exactly, but the game flows really well once you get into the rhythm of it. anyone who's played a game in this genre will know what i mean by that; you get into a routine, find out what works and what doesn't, and then you start scaling up and becoming a giant capitalist with a zillion weird lil machines churning out products, earning you a tidy profit. in sandrock, somehow, even early game resources kept feeling worthwhile to amass, and i ended up doing my best to figure out what to spend the day in in order to keep the machines running with stuff which would allow me to most efficiently complete next days' comissions.


[h3]the subjective[/h3]
[b]character art[/b]
love it or hate it, portia character designs were distinct. in sandrock, the style is a bit less pronounced. personally, i like it better this way, as i found the portia characters veered between distinct and grotesque.

[b]focus/direction[/b]
this game definitely requires you to explore and experiment a bit. a lot of information is available in-game, especially once you've discovered something e.g. a material will have details on how to procure it once obtained.

[h3]the bad[/h3]
[b]a sense of confusion and/or being overwhelmed[/b]
this game has the exact same issue as portia: it's front-loaded, and it doesn't always succeed in explaining all of its' mechanics due to the sheer amount of stuff there is to see and do. some things go completely unexplained and just sit there in the ui, staring at you accusatorily, daring you to interact with them and finding out what will happen. 
there's a lot of systems which is all fine and dandy, but you're also not incentivized to take your time figuring them all out. this makes especially the first few days of the game play out in a hectic fashion. i had to re-learn a bunch since it's been a hot minute since playing mtap, and starting this fresh would probably be worse. it's a shame, because i can imagine people being scared off by this. heck, i put down portia and almost never came back to it when i first played it, due to this exact issue.

[b]simultaneously polished and full of skung[/b]
this game contains nintendo levels of detail and polish in some areas, and gets extremely skungy in others, and these disparate levels of polish overlap at times. to illustrate: i'm watching a nicely choreographed cutscene complete with great lighting and what appears to be a blend of mo-cap and manually done character animations, lending it legitimacy while keeping consistent with the general art direction of the game. the cutscene ends. my character automatically starts pathing towards an arbitrary position, gets snagged on a fence, runs in place for a moment, phases out of existence, reappears a few meters away, and two npcs pop in next to them. all the while little shrubs are waving in the wind as a tumbleweed rolls by in the beautifully rendered sand drifts.
to be honest, this could be seen as a positive as well, considering the fact that all of portia nested comfortably in the janky skungzone, so it's a triump pathea have managed to elevate their work to this level. however, the disparity means that the skungness stands out more admidst the nintendonean polish levels, whereas in portia the entire vibe was skung so it just fit.

review:
23 oct 23:
the story has an intriguing story and it is quite rewarding to see the impact you make on sandrock. without any spoilers, i'm very much looking forward to the next chapter in the "my time" world. i think most of the characters feel unique (to the other townsfolk, at least). the romance storylines i followed were sweet, but there are some characters that you will not interact with or be able to romance until very late game, which is kind of frustrating.

but to be honest, the game has a laundry list of basic quality audio, graphics, and  issues, even as the release date is right around the corner. also, if you grind through the storylines, some progression issues and quest overlapping are going to happen (at least during the pre-release phases).

much like its moniker, sandrock needs further polishing before it becomes "the jewel of the eufala".

review:
having finished the game i can say this game was much, much bigger than my time at portia to begin with.

now for the rest of the game, i've loved it, i think i would have loved it even more if i hadn't played it piecemeal from the early access so everyone gets it better now waiting for the full release.

the story is fun and delightful with nice complete arcs.

i find myself loving everything around, the characters are delightful and varied with their personalities. 

the quests all seem to make sense and the side quests are nice, the main quests mostly aren't timed so you set your pace, mostly... there are forced gaps/delays, so if you are like me that means breakneck speed. core gameplay loop is solid.

though my favorite self-indulgence in this game is the fact that everything you make that is bigger than hand sized exists in the world. you can go out and see it all, from elevators, to shrubs, to buildings and more.  the world really does change with your actions and it shows there in the world, 

there are still some bugs and little minor things but as long as you don't care too much you will enjoy the game.

review:
if you played and liked my time at portia, go ahead and grab this. it's a bigger and better game in basically every way.

if you haven't played it, well, this is a farming game where you don't farm much. specially because now you are in the middle of the desert, and you can't just fill your watering can from a well. instead, most of what you do is building; do some ruin diving, collect resources, smelt ore, and bang out the things sandrockers commission you to make. sleep and repeat.

in the meantime, you will have the chance to get to know these colorful characters better and learn a fair bit about the post-apocalyptic world they live in. with a much longer duration, this game manages to flesh out much of the worldbuilding the first title only alluded to.

production values are not in the aaa ballpark. the ea version i played had some pretty bad pop-in issues, and while most of the dialogue is voiced, some side content isn't. still, this is a game with heart, and if you are looking for something cozy to put a solid hundred hours in, you can certainly do a lot worse.

review:
tldr - this game is a gem with lots to do to keep you busy and runs well with minimal bugs.

   long main story, tons of sides, loveable characters, and scratches that builder itch you may have.  most of the lines are voice acted.  can get repetitive later levels and the story, whilst good, goes off the rails.  overall totally worth the price per content as in my first play though took 140 hours and i still didn't do everything i wanted... on play through 2 this time for a better set up to /romance all the characters =p.  oh, and you can save almost anytime minus like a super important event, but can usually save before or after, you don't have to wait for the sleep cycle.

  there are minor bugs, usually fixed with a reload.  some resources are a little too limited imo that commissions will flood your board.  resources start getting cluttered late game.  some features that were in portia are not here.  the game is set up for dlcs, which is fine.  i'm curious to see the generation features.  one of my npc couples had a baby later in the game, was a total mind melt, though this feature for the main character won't be released till launch.
 
  i can't really comment on the multiplayer aspect, only from what i've read from other users.  but, i'm judging this game as a standalone single player experience.  and at it's core, is a great game.  if there was some way to make multiplayer have different homesteads, i think that would make it ideal, but i think it's just sharing one property.

9/10
